title: In Brooklyn, Challenging the Party Establishment
description: When their excitement of watching Barack Obama win the presidency began to fade and the reality of the local political machine  something they wanted to be a part of  had set in, Rachel Lauter and Matt Cowherd founded New Kings Democrats, the Brooklyn-based, grass-roots political organization.

title: Storms Impact on Oil Industry Is Felt at Gasoline Pumps
description: HOUSTON  Ports along the Gulf of Mexico are closed to fuel barges. Part of the biggest pipeline between Texas and New York has stopped flowing. Refineries and gas stations are flooded. Drilling rigs in the biggest shale field in Texas are running low on diesel supplies.

title: South of the Border, Migrants Eye a Storm-Torn Texas
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico  When a group of migrants staying in a shelter in this border city heard last weekend that Hurricane Harvey was barreling down on Texas, they did not wait. They saw an opportunity to ford the Rio Grande and slip into the United States, using the storm as cover.

title: Mattis Insists He and Trump Are on the Same Page on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Jim Mattis insisted on Thursday that he was not at odds with President Trump over North Korea and asserted that the media had misinterpreted his recent remarks on how to deal with Pyongyang.

title: Officials Eye Euphrates River Valley as Last Stand for ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Islamic State fighters are expected to make their last stand in a series of Euphrates River Valley towns and villages that American-backed Syrian and Iraqi forces are not expected to attack for months, American officials said Thursday.

title: How Shelley Worrell, Creator of CaribBeing, Spends Her Sundays
description: Growing up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Shelley Vidia Worrell saw her Caribbean roots reflected everywhere. So as an adult, in an effort to celebrate and preserve them, she created CaribBeing, which hosts film series and art exhibitions, and which just completed a monthlong residency in a shipping container at the Brooklyn Museum. When not at the museum or working with the mayors office to designate an official Little Caribbean in Flatbush, Ms. Worrell, 40, has been checking out her neighbors preparations for the West Indian American Day Parade, which will be held on Sept. 4 in Crown Heights. She lives in a brownstone with her husband, Janluk Stanislas, a filmmaker.

title: Quotation of the Day: Metropolis Awash in Stagnant Brew of Chemicals, Sewage and Garbage
description: Theres no need to test it. Its contaminated. Theres millions of contaminants.

title: Stephon Marbury Stops at N.Y.U., as His Story Continues
description: Stephon Marbury walked into a secluded courtyard off East 12th Street in Lower Manhattan Wednesday afternoon and settled into a chair between two tables stacked with boxes of shoes.

title: What Sandy Can Teach Harvey About Recovery
description: Disasters are meant to inform each other, the mistakes of one recovery observed and presumably avoided in the next. Those tasked with remaking Houston in the wake of the current devastation, will have a thick playbook of error on which to reflect.

title: Drag Racing for Any Car: 12 Seconds of Pure Adrenaline
description: You really think a Prius can blow the doors off a Hyundai Elantra? On Wednesday nights, the place to settle such a question is Englishtown, N.J., where $20 can buy drivers three runs on the quarter-mile drag strip at Raceway Park.

title: What North Koreas Missile Tests Look Like to a South Korean Reporter
description: SYDNEY, Australia  North Korea fired a ballistic missile over northern Japan this week, prompting the government in Tokyo to warn residents in its path to take cover, and leading to another round of questions about whether war will soon strike the Korean Peninsula.

title: Discussing North Korea
description: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

title: Though Federer Survives 2nd 5-Set Match, His Play Invites Questions
description: The signs were there before the United States Open began, even if many devoted fans refused to recognize them. Roger Federer had injured his 36-year-old back during a tournament in Montreal two weeks ago, then had withdrawn from the next tournament in Cincinnati to rest it.

title: Texas Abortion Restriction Is Temporarily Blocked
description: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a Texas law that would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion.

title: Dave Dombrowski, Ever the Tinkerer, Readies the Red Sox for October
description: The doors are now locked to all newcomers hoping to play past Oct. 1. Once September arrives, baseball executives cannot add pieces to help in the postseason. Everyone eligible for a playoff roster must be in his organization before Sept. 1. The gangs all there now, for some lucky franchise. We just dont know which.

title: How Federal Flood Insurance Puts Homes at Risk
description: It was clear long before Hurricane Harvey slammed into Texas that the National Flood Insurance Program, the governments most important means of recovering from such disasters, needed to be overhauled. It fails to account for the full extent of flood risk, encourages development in areas known to be flood-prone and is not realistically funded.

title: Without Wasting a Word
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Dont tell anyone, but this is a rough week for me. I took The Boy to college for his first semester, and Im incredibly proud of how much hes grown up in the past few years. I love the young man hes become. Hes outgrown whatever teenage quirks he had, and hes really nice to be around. And now hes leaving. By the way, todays puzzle is a really nice one by Patrick Berry.

title: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend
description: If youre lucky enough to have time off this Labor Day weekend, put in a few extra hours with a movie or two about the workplace. Whether they are set in cube farms or factories, the stories of workers struggles and triumphs will always have a place in the movies. Here are 7 to start with. Get to work.

title: For 18 Hours, 3 Men in Houston Fought for Survival in Hurricane Harvey
description: Clinging to a tree branch in torrential rain and howling winds, Ruaridh Connellan fought against the ferocious current of Houstons Greens Bayou. His body was weak and under water. Are we going to die, he said over and over again to a colleague hugging the trunk of the tree.

title: Soccer Star Kylian Mbappes Move to Paris St.-Germain Is Completed
description: Forward Kylian Mbappes expected move to Paris St.-Germain finally went through Thursday evening, as Monaco loaned him until the end of the season along with an option to make the move permanent. No financial details were given by P.S.G. in its statement, but the permanent deal would be from 2018 to 2022.

title: Corrections: September 1, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whos Allowed to Hold Hands?
description: On our first date, I dared to give her a lingering hug on a crowded subway platform on West Fourth Street, an unusual display of physical affection on my part, which I blamed on the wine. It was the start of spring, the city in bloom.

title: Inside One of Houstons Improvised Shelters
description: One family describes how they lost everything in the flooding before being taken to one of the many shelters in Houston.

title: Word + Quiz: flippant
Texas, Brexit, Emmanuel Macron: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: With Aaron Judge Struggling at the Plate, Greg Bird Steps Up for the Yankees
description: A couple of days off, a demotion in the batting order and the presence of a real judge  Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the United States Supreme Court  in the Judges Chambers at Yankee Stadium did little to spur Aaron Judge out of his second-half funk on Thursday.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Narcos and Diana, 7 Days
description: Narcos returns on Netflix without its main character. And a new documentary on Diana, Princess of Wales, focuses on the week after her death.

title: Plastic Bags
Boats Carrying Rohingya Fleeing Myanmar Sink, Killing 46
description: HONG KONG  At least 46 people believed to be Rohingya fleeing violence in western Myanmar have been found dead on the banks of a river along the boundary with Bangladesh, Bangladeshi officials said on Friday.

title: The 1990s Gave Us the Trump Teens
description: It began on the slopes in Aspen the last week of 1989. A real estate mogul and his paramour, a model named Marla Maples, had the misfortune to walk straight into the path of the moguls wife, Ivana Trump. There was a confrontation. And a short time later the gossip columns were consumed with the first juicy scandal of the 1990s. One tabloid headline went so far as to declare Best Sex I Ever Had, a reference (some say apocryphal) to how Ms. Maples rated Donald Trump.

title: The Urban Revival Is Over
description: TORONTO  For all the concern about the gentrification, rising housing prices and the growing gap between the rich and poor in our leading cities, an even bigger threat lies on the horizon: The urban revival that swept across America over the past decade or two may be in danger. As it turns out, the much-ballyhooed new age of the city might be giving way to a great urban stall-out.

title: Make Pot Legal for Veterans With Traumatic Brain Injury
description: The explosion that wounded me during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in 2010 left me with a traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress. In 2012 I was medically retired from the Marine Corps because of debilitating migraines, vertigo and crippling depression. After a nine-year career, I sought care from the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: In Praise of Equipoise
description: The Lebanese-born writer Amin Maalouf made an interesting point about identity: Other people often pick ours for us. The anti-Semite elevates the Jewish consciousness in the Jew. The Sunni radical elevates Shiite consciousness in the Shiite.

title: The Week the Earth Stood Still
description: On Monday, most of us were still trying to fathom what nine trillion gallons of water would feel like  that hydraulic cube over downtown Houston, four miles square and two miles high. And then the cube doubled to become the most extreme rain event in American history.

title: Blocking a Bad Immigration Law in Texas
description: Anyone watching the storm devastation in Texas had to be stirred by the mix of resilient victims and valiant rescuers  a mix of people from all backgrounds united in a struggle for survival. The heroic images of community resolve could not have been a more apt backdrop for the decision by a federal judge in Texas in midstorm to block the Republican-controlled state governments attempt to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities and make them enforce federal immigration laws.

title: Red Soxs Gentle Bunt Draws a Furious Response From C.C. Sabathia
description: It was a delicately hit ball, a bunt placed by Eduardo Nunez just in front of the pitchers mound in the first inning on Thursday. But for C.C. Sabathia, who came down off the hill to field it, the bunt came saddled with a gesture, one that seemed bold enough to awaken a bear in winter.

title: In House of Z, the Jagged Arc of Zac Posen
description: Zac Posens mythic ascent to fashion superstardom is retold in House of Z, a documentary by Sandy Chronopoulos available for streaming on Wednesday, Sept. 6, at Vogue.com/houseofz. The son of an artist and a lawyer living in SoHo, Mr. Posen first draped fabric on dolls as a toddler. As a teen at Saint Anns School in Brooklyn, he turned the actresses Paz de la Huerta, Jemima Kirke and Lola Schnabel into muses. While a student at Central St. Martins in London, he designed a pink silk dress for Naomi Campbell that was passed from woman to woman before catching the eye of a reporter for The New York Times. Buyers came calling and Mr. Posen set up a studio with the help of his mother and sister. A star was born. He was 20.

title: Quad Cinemas Nicolas Roeg Retrospective Highlights a Directors Lens Work
description: The great British filmmaker Nicolas Roeg was a cinematographer before he was a director, and the partial retrospective of his work now underway at the Quad Cinema is wisely including two classic films highlighting his lens work.

title: Company Helps Take Those Dog Days of Summer for a Walk
description: The official last day of summer is not until Sept. 22, but lets face it: Its essentially over after Labor Day, and were all going to gripe about how it went by faster than ever this year and we didnt do enough.

title: Resonant Bodies Festival: Witness the Process at Roulette
description: The art making feels unusually personal during the Resonant Bodies Festival, which began in 2013 and has swiftly become something to look forward to each year. A wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music, lately hosted at Roulette in Brooklyn, it follows a simple formula: Three nights (Tuesday through Thursday, Sept. 5-7), three singers per night, one 45-minute set per singer. The vocalists are the curators.

title: A Century of Jacob Lawrence
description: Jacob Lawrence may be best known for his Great Migration series of paintings, depicting the movement northward of millions of black Americans from the South in the early 20th century. But the artist himself was born in Atlantic City, after his own parents made the journey. And this week, the SCAD Museum of Art in Savannah, Ga., will mark Lawrences 100th birthday on Thursday, Sept. 7, with the opening of Lines of Influence, an exhibition that traces both the sources of his inspiration and his enduring resonance with contemporary artists.

title: Alexandra Pirici Installs a Threshold at the High Line
description: Anyone strolling the High Line between Tuesday, Sept. 5, and Thursday may encounter traffic in the Rail Yards, the parks northernmost section. At 30th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues, performers will create a moving barrier for pedestrians to pass through. The event, from 4 to 7 p.m., is Alexandra Piricis Threshold, a work that the artist describes not as a performance but as an ongoing action.

title: Teaching Activities for: Putting Art on Wheels and Taking It Back to the Street
description: Before reading the article:

title: Notes From the Book Review Archives
description: This week Lisa Schwarzbaum reviews a new book about Nora Ephron and her romantic comedies. Ephron was a regular contributor to the Book Review, and in this essay from 1986, she ruminates on the unexpected advantages of revision. Below is an excerpt.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Write a Love Letter
description: You need a minimum of one hour, says Sonia Cancian, an assistant professor of history at Zayed University in Dubai. Find a quiet place away from distractions and spend time just thinking about what you want to communicate. A letter has a remarkable way of transpiring feelings, emotions, honesty, sincerity and authenticity, says Cancian, who insists on the singular power of a love letter even in the era of more immediate communication methods like video chat or texting.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Coercing Your Wife Into Writing a Memoir
description: Nicholas writes: My wife had an insane childhood. Her father made her sneak into other peoples gardens to steal orchids so he could sell them. A family friend would come and go, with tales of faking Scud missile launches in Iraq. Not to mention long-ago connections with the Crowninshields, the money long run out. She doesnt want to embarrass her relatives. But I think she should write a book.

title: Poem: The Widows Neighborhood
description: Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: Behind the Cover: 9.3.17
description: Gail Bichler, design director: This weeks cover story is about a new cast of characters in Washington who are using their relationships to Donald Trumps 2016 campaign as a ticket into the capitals clubby influence industry. To underscore their outsider status and their sometimes unorthodox methods  we hit on the idea of a D.I.Y. flier.

title: New Sentences: From Autumn, by Karl Ove Knausgaard
description: To turn 40 is to realize that ones limitations will last ones whole life through, but also to know that all the time, whether one likes it or not, and whether one is aware of it or not, new layers are being added to ones character, a type of knowledge and insight that isnt directed towards the future, towards what will come to pass or one day be accomplished, but towards the here and now, in the things you do every day, in what you think about them and what you understand of them.

title: Dont Mess With Pepe
description: If Dr. Seuss Cat in the Hat emerged victorious from a property rights battle, and so did Maurice Sendaks Max, why not Pepe the comic zine frog?

title: On the Road: Two Children Brave the Irish Famine
description: GRACE By Paul Lynch 354 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Feminist Fiction From the Philippines, Written 50 Years Ago
description: To enter the world of The Woman Who Had Two Navels and Tales of the Tropical Gothic, your faith must bend to the following: Time travel exists. Shapeshifting is possible. And a woman could be in power.

title: Epic Stories That Expand the Universal Family Plot
description: Family sagas write history through microcosm, tracing a clans rise, survival and, more often than not, ultimate dissolution. Thomas Manns healthy bourgeois Buddenbrooks succumb to decadent sterility; Gabriel Garca Mrquezs Buendas are erased by a hurricane; the Starks of Winterfell are massacred in the Riverlands. A family is sacrificed to time, and in their entrails readers find auguries of larger motions. The critic Frank Kermode believed that novels developed alongside a loss of faith in biblical chronology, as substitutes for Adam and Eves universal family plot. He is borne out by recent years fruitful crop of epics rooted in the familiar soil of fathers and daughters, mothers and sons, blood, sex, bastardy and inheritance.

title: Suspense Fiction That Mines the Terrain of Female Guilt
description: FINAL DEMAND By Deborah Moggach 225 pp. Overlook, $27.

title: Fall in Italy: Lovely Weather, Lower Prices
description: Italy is always in style as a vacation destination for travelers from the United States, and this year is no exception. The country is a best-seller within the travel networks Virtuoso and Signature Travel Network, the latter of which has a double-digit growth in sales in 2017 for Italy trips. Flight searches are also up, but, fortunately, airfare prices are down: between May 1 and July 10, Cheapflights.com saw flight searches to Milan and Rome from the United States for travel for this September and October increase 43 percent, compared with the same period last year while ticket prices dropped by 18 percent to Milan and by 17 percent to Rome. Misty Ewing, the global head of public relations for Virtuoso, encourages value-seekers to consider a fall Italian getaway. Prices drop significantly, but the weather is still beautiful, she said.

title: Mythic Revenge, a Mythic Film and Possibly Mythic Memories
description: Louise Penny wrote the book on escapist mysteries  a dozen of them, in fact, almost all set in the sheltered Canadian village of Three Pines. It was a haven, a buffer, from the cares and cruelty of the world, she tells us in GLASS HOUSES (Minotaur, $28.99), a place seemingly so free of malice and discord that Armand Gamache, chief superintendent of the Sret du Qubec, and his wife, Reine-Marie, have made it their sanctuary. One of the pleasures of returning to this series is visiting old friends in the village like Gabri and Olivier, who run the convivial B&B; the artist Clara Morrow, whose startling portraits will haunt you; and (a personal favorite) Ruth Zardo, a poet who accurately describes herself as a crazy old woman who prays for Satan and has a duck.

title: A Decades-old Detective Series Is Still on Top
description: THE ABCS OF MYSTERY: Back in 1982, when Sue Grafton wrote the first novel in what was to become her career-making Alphabet series, she knew she was taking a risk. It was a crapshoot, she told NPRs Dwayne Brown. I wasnt even sure I could sell A Is for Alibi. But she wanted to get back into solo writing after a career in Hollywood, and detective fiction called. The risk paid off: The Alphabet books, which star the Southern California-based private investigator Kinsey Millhone, have been steadily enthralling readers with heists, betrayals and murders for the last 35 years.

title: Unesco World Heritage Sites 2017 Picks Range From Eritrea to England
description: Unesco annually expands its list of World Heritage Sites, and this years class of inductees, announced in July, offers both stimulation for travelers, with a rich and varied group of intriguing sites, and a reminder, especially with its remote and more vulnerable picks, that the list itself is not about tourism.

title: Manufacturing Is a Bright Spot in a Subdued Jobs Report
description: MACUNGIE, Pa.  At the sprawling Mack Trucks factory here, the last of the workers laid off in 2016 after sales slowed down are back on the line, and for the first time in years, the company is hiring new employees.

title: Looking for a London Vacation Rental? We Tried the Plum Guide
description: The popularity of vacation home rentals in London has surged following last summers Brexit referendum: Existing companies with an international presence, such as Airbnb, Onefinestay and Oasis have all reported a significant jump in rentals, while a handful of new players offering rentals only in London, such as the Plum Guide and Cuckooz, have seen their businesses grow rapidly.

title: Floodwaters Inundate Beaumont as Houston Assesses Damage
description: HOUSTON  As Southeast Texas residents emerged by the thousands from shelters, motels and friends houses to return to flood-damaged homes, others remained in the grip of the crisis on Friday, cut off by still-rising floodwaters and living without running water for a second day.

title: Ken Burns and Lynn Novick Tackle the Vietnam War
description: Ken Burns shot to fame in 1990 with The Civil War, which drew record audiences for PBS and jump-started a revival of popular interest in the subject. Nearly three decades and more than 20 documentaries later, he is perhaps the nations most trusted historical brand, as much an icon of American-ness as baseball (the subject of his nine-part 1994 documentary) and apple pie (one of the few classic American themes he hasnt taken on).

title: My Liberia: A Vacation Paradise
description: On the last day of my familys big trip home to Liberia, the staff of Mamba Point Hotel threw an impromptu going away party for my 6-year-old nephew, Cooper.

title: Inside New York Citys Priciest Rentals
description: When Allan Rothstein decided to rent his NoHo loft on Crosby Street a few years ago, the $22,000-a-month price tag wasnt a major concern.

title: The Little Theater That Could
description: The wilting three-story building in Greenwich Village that houses the 13th Street Repertory Company creaked and groaned as its artistic director, Joe Battista, gave a tour of its theater one afternoon in July. The Repertory opened in 1972 and is one of the oldest Off Off Broadway theaters in New York. Mr. Battista walked past its 65 tattered seats and onto its stage.

title: Shot by Shot: Building a Scene in Ken Burns and Lynn Novicks Vietnam Epic
description: The Vietnam War, Ken Burns and Lynn Novicks panoramic 18-hour television documentary, includes 10 set-piece battle scenes documenting the action from multiple perspectives. Among them is the battle of Binh Gia, which took place in late December 1964, 40 miles southeast of Saigon.

title: Kenya Supreme Court Nullifies Presidential Election
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In a historic ruling and a first in Africa, Kenyas Supreme Court nullified on Friday the re-election of a sitting president, ordering a new vote to be held within 60 days after finding that the outcome last month had been tainted by irregularities.

title: Harvey, Kenya, Harriet Tubman: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: In City of Ruins, Philippines Battle Against ISIS Rages On
description: MARAWI, Philippines  The houses still standing after more than three months of fierce urban combat in Marawi are barely holding on  pocked with bullet holes on the outside and blackened by fire from within.

title: Tending to the Rituals of My Lost and Found Father
description: He says its his lucky bottle and not to touch it.

title: New York Today: A Labor Day Staycation
description: Good morning on this fabulous Friday.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Biting Midges, Coffee and Stronger Brains
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Does Cooking Boost Nutrients in Tomatoes and Spinach?
description: Q. Is it true tomatoes and spinach release more of their nutrients when theyve been cooked?

title: From Guerrilla Fighter to Myanmar Peace Negotiator
description: YANGON, Myanmar

title: Work, Work, Work. Love, Love, Love.
description: When Stephanie Horbaczewski met Gordon Clemons, romance was the last thing on her mind.

title: Morning Agenda: The Next Big Battle for Business Is Immigration
description: The next potential battle between the Trump administration and business leaders is near, and its on immigration.

title: Jason Fried of Basecamp on the Importance of Writing Skills
description: This interview with Jason Fried, chief executive of Basecamp, a web-based project management tool, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Green Light for Art Criminals?
description: LONDON  The horrific Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed the lives of about 80 residents of an apartment block here in June, has had a number of unforeseen consequences.

title: When Colleagues Wont Stop Talking Politics
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Willie Nelson, Roky Erickson, Eric Clapton: Twang, Psychedelia and Blues
description: With all eyes on a hurricane-torn Texas, its perpetually touring musicians carry a spirit of resilience. Willie Nelson, despite recent respiratory problems, has been barnstorming across America with his encompassing repertoire of Americana. This weekend he headlines the Outlaw Music Festival of roots-rock and country in amphitheaters: Friday, Sept. 8, at PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., and Saturday at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y. The lineup includes his sons band, Lukas Nelson and Promise of the Real, along with Sheryl Crow, the Avett Brothers and Margo Price. The paladin of Texas psychedelia, Roky Erickson  who led the 13th Floor Elevators in the 1960s and returned, after some difficult years personally, with garage-rock visions of aliens, demons and redemption  performs in Brooklyn on Wednesday and Thursday at Rough Trade and Jersey City on Friday at White Eagle Hall. Meanwhile, Eric Clapton is bringing Austin bluesmen as openers  and rivals  when he plays Madison Square Garden on Thursday and Friday, sharing the bill with the incendiary guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and with Jimmie Vaughan, a founder of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.

title: What Do Harrison Ford and a Homicidal Clown Have in Common?
description: It only took a day for a sinister 31-year-old clown to outpace the combined powers of Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson, a.k.a The Rock.

title: David Litt, an Obama Speechwriter Who Wants No Credit
description: Washington is filled with political operatives who inflate their importance and take credit, oftentimes where it might not be due.

title: Amanda Seales of Insecure Revisits Her Harlem Haunts
description: As Amanda Seales strode into Ginnys Supper Club, the nightspot under the Red Rooster in Harlem on a recent Thursday, a young woman pulled her aside, saying, You are fabulous, honey. At the fans request, the two took a pout-perfect selfie.

title: Teenagers in The Times: August 2017
description: After a summer break, we present the first edition of Teenagers in The Times of the new school year. On the first Friday of each month, youll find a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.

title: Michael Dell, Tech Billionaire, Pledges $36 Million in Harvey Relief
description: Michael Dell, the billionaire Texan who founded Dell Technologies, has pledged $36 million of his foundations money to help disaster relief efforts in the wake of Hurricane Harvey.

title: California Today: Firefighters, at Less Than $2 an Hour
description: Good morning.

title: Deporting Dreamers
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Harvey Updates: Fire and Smoke Again Engulf Chemical Plant Near Houston
description: Fire engulfed part of a chemical plant northeast of Houston on Friday evening, sending thick black smoke high into the sky, a statement from Arkema, the owner of the plant, confirmed. It was the same facility where, on Thursday, a chemical storage trailer exploded, setting off a fire. Flooding from Harvey, once a Category 4 hurricane that hit southeast Texas last week, had knocked out the refrigeration system needed to keep the chemicals stable.

title: Capturing Action Just Off the Court at the U.S. Open
description: I am always attracted to the edges because they define shape and give context. And I always seek a spark of photographic magic on the edges of light and shadow. So when I was tasked to cover the opening days of the United States Open this year, I found myself looking to the margins of both the action and the light as the worlds premier players performed an exquisitely elegant dance of athleticism and grace with the assistance of an army of support: ball boys and ball girls, line judges and members of the security staff, working in view of a sea of awe-inspired fans, myself included. I worked the courtside edges, from Arthur Ashe Stadium to the practice courts, to incorporate some of those people into photographs that usually strive to be free of distractions, and I allowed myself the pleasure of finding beauty as the players tried to gain their own edge.

title: Trump Again Lashes Out at Comeys Handling of Clinton Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Friday lashed out anew at the F.B.I. director he fired in May, charging that James B. Comey had exonerated Hillary Clinton before fully completing the investigation into her use of a private email server.

title: Switching Between Apples iOS and Googles Android
description: Q. How hard is it to switch smartphone systems from Android to the new iPhone that is coming out this fall? Do I have to buy all new apps? And if I ever want to change back to Android, how much of a hassle is it?

title: Farhads and Nicks Week in Review: Ubers New Boss and Amazons New Supermarket
description: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week so Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter based in Seattle, filled in.

title: A 16-Room Penthouse at the Pierre Sells for $44 Million
description: One of the citys most expensive apartment listings  a rambling triplex perched atop the venerable Pierre Hotel overlooking Central Park  has finally sold after more than four years on and off the market.

title: Football Favoritism at F.S.U.: The Price One Teacher Paid
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  As the Florida State University football team was marching to a national title in the fall of 2013, the school was investigating allegations of academic favoritism involving a half-dozen of its leading players, including one who scored the winning touchdown in the championship game.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Alex Trebek
description: The Jeopardy! host sketched his answers at his desk with both a regular and an Extra Fine Point Sharpie while sipping a glass of chardonnay.

title: Nafta Negotiations: Whats at Stake in the Second Round
description: Trade negotiators from Canada, Mexico and the United States resume discussions on Friday over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: As Season Opens, a Fresh Set of Eyes and the Usual Suspects
description: In December, the human element in selecting a national champion, so longed for during the 16 years of the Bowl Championship Series automatonic algorithm, finally showed up in the College Football Playoffs third season.

title: The 10 Games That Will Determine College Footballs Playoff
description: By the end of the season, most of the College Football Playoff contenders 12 or 13 games will seem, in retrospect, like insignificant and anonymous blowouts of weaker opposition. But a few games will prove defining for who was beaten, and where and how. These games will be crucial in deciding who gets in and who is left out of the four-team postseason.

title: A Well-Choreographed Apartment
description: For Kelly Devine, the choreographer of Come From Away and Escape to Margaritaville, furnishing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.

title: In Kelly Devines Apartment, Even the Furniture Has to Audition
description: The choreographer Kelly Devine grew up in Los Angeles, and stuck around for the first two decades of her career to stage dances for film, television, videos and commercials. She moved east a dozen years ago to focus on Broadway musicals, and has since worked on Rock of Ages, Rocky, Doctor Zhivago and Come From Away, in the process picking up two Tony Award nominations. Next up: Escape to Margaritaville.

title: A Clam Chowder That Tastes Like Summer
description: A traditional chowder of corn, potatoes and clams is like a clambake in a bowl, minus the lobster. Everything bobs about in a delicious broth, highlighting the sweetness of each ingredient.

title: The August Jobs Numbers Are Weak. Dont Blame Trump.
description: The details of the August jobs numbers are disappointing, though hardly catastrophic.

title: When Office Meetings Leave the Office Behind
description: Entrepreneurs have a reputation for working long hours to get their businesses up and running, leading some of their employees to a quick burnout.

title: A Whirlwind Year for a Workaholic, Mindy Kaling
description: When we last saw The Mindy Project, a newly married Mindy Lahiri was gazing out a subway window when a shadow of doubt crossed her face. Which was crazy, because wasnt this what shed always wanted?

title: Russian Election Hacking Efforts, Wider Than Previously Known, Draw Little Scrutiny
description: The calls started flooding in from hundreds of irate North Carolina voters just after 7 a.m. on Election Day last November.

title: Lasting Merit Found in a Tuberculosis Vaccine Invented a Century Ago
description: Tuberculosis kills almost two million people a year. A perfect vaccine could save many of them, but the one now in use  invented in the 1920s and known as BCG, for Bacillus Calmette-Gurin  has so many flaws that some countries, including the United States, have never adopted it.

title: Agreement on Construction Workers Safety, but Not So Much on Bill
description: When thousands of union workers gathered for a raucous rally near City Hall in late 2015, after a spate of deaths and injuries in construction accidents, they urged local officials to adopt stronger safety measures.

title: Lattice to Seek Trumps Approval for Chinese-Backed Buyout
description: The Trump administration will soon face a test of its China economic policy, as a chipmaker plans to appeal to the White House for approval of its proposed sale to a Chinese-backed buyer.

title: Summer Was Not So Hellish for Commuters at Penn Station
description: After the recent reviews, Amtrak may want to consider producing a sequel to the summer of hell.

title: Under Observation, Some Hospital Patients Face Big Bills
description: In April, Nancy Niemi entered Vidant Medical Center in Greenville, N.C., with cardiac problems. She stayed four nights, at one point receiving a coronary stent.

title: Shelley Berman, Stand-Up Comic Who Skewered Modern Life, Dies at 92
description: Shelley Berman, whose brittle persona and anxiety-ridden observations helped redefine stand-up comedy in the late 1950s and early 60s, died early Friday morning at his home in Bell Canyon, Calif. He was 92.

title: Pink Panther and Decoy Return on Disc
description: Its a case of good cop, bad cop: The 1957-58 series Decoy, an obscure gem from the golden age of network television, has been issued in its entirety on a three-disc set from Film Chest Media Group. And all six movies about the blundering Inspector Clouseau, starring Peter Sellers and directed by Blake Edwards (who also did much of the writing), are out from Shout! Factory as the six-Blu-ray Pink Panther Film Collection.

title: Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor, Living Out Loud (and Quietly)
description: Madonnas 1998 album, Ray of Light, bore many gifts, not least of which was the friendship between Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor.

title: Library Cards Unlock Film Vaults
description: A few years ago, back when video rental stores were still around but clearly an endangered species (Tower Records had shut down, Blockbuster was in trouble and Netflix was still dealing in DVDs), I was chatting with a friend, a fellow cinephile experiencing an economic downturn. (As it happened, he had worked for Tower.) It was difficult to keep up with classic releases on home video, particularly stuff from the Criterion Collection, he said, but fortunately for him titles would eventually turn up at his local public library. And he didnt have to wait long for them either, since few people in his New Jersey town (which had once been mine) were keen on art or foreign films.

title: Harvey, Part II
description: A new state motto?

title: Shania Twain Walked Out on Top. Now She Wants Back In.
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The last time Shania Twain released an album  the experimental country-but-not-quite opus Up!  it sold 874,000 copies in its first week, and went on to receive the Recording Industry Association of Americas diamond certification for 10 million copies sold, her third album in a row to reach that milestone.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: True Detective Will Return for a Third Season on HBO
description: Its actually coming back.

title: Your Everyday Makeup Questions, Answered
description: Advice from experts on the best ways to apply your daily makeup and, along the way, clear up a few confounding makeup questions.

title: Womens Hockey League Will Pay Players for First Time
description: The Canadian Womens Hockey League will pay players for the first time in its 11-year history beginning this season, the league announced Friday.

title: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend
description: From Modern Times to Office Space, here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.

title: A Tasting Menu of Yelps and Hums at the Resonant Bodies Festival
description: For a city obsessed with tasting menus and small-plate smorgasbords, there is a fitting festival of experimental vocal music.

title: U.S. Open Results: Marin Cilic Loses; New Aunt Venus Williams Wins
description: Stay here for live results and analysis from Day 5 of the U.S. Open.

title: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in December
description: New movies and TV shows are added to streaming platforms each month. Here are the titles we think are most interesting in December.

title: Cecilia Bartoli, Last Seen With a Beard, May Return to New York
description: SALZBURG, Austria  It has been nearly a decade since the beloved Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli last sang in New York. David Letterman, Jon Stewart and others have been known to grow beards when theyve left the citys limelight. But the whiskers Ms. Bartoli was sporting recently werent quite of that variety.

title: Why a 24-Year-Old Chipmaker Is One of Techs Hot Prospects
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  Engineers at CTA.ai, an imaging-technology start-up in Poland, are trying to popularize a more comfortable alternative to the colonoscopy. To do so, they are using computer chips that are best known to video game fans.

title: Singing and Chattering: The Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
description: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what's delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: How Low-Cost Airlines Alter the Economics of Flying
description: For more than three years, the average one-way fare between Detroit and Philadelphia never dipped below $308, and sometimes moved higher, topping $385 at one point.

title: After Harvey, Houston Showed Up
description: HOUSTON  Houston is sprawling, made of dozens of little Houstons. Bellaire is not Montrose is not the Heights is not Sugar Land, and its possible to go years without stepping foot in one community or the other. Each one vibrates on its own frequency.

title: A Lifes Many Acts Culminate in the Kitchen at NA/NA in Paris
description: When Nathaly Nicolas-Ianniello opened NA/NA in Paris in 2015, not only was it the first time she had ever worked as a chef, but it was her first job in a restaurant. A daring thing for anyone to do, but she was 52, and many of her friends thought she was nuts.

title: A Controversial Restoration That Wipes Away the Past
description: CHARTRES, France  The pilgrim did not find what he was searching for. As a child, Patrice Bertrand heard his mother recount details of her visit to the shrine of the famous Black Madonna of Chartres Cathedral, 60 miles southwest of Paris. Now Mr. Bertrand, 41, of Nantes, was following in her footsteps. But he was perplexed by what he discovered: The statue I came to see is not here anymore, he said. The Black Madonna had become white.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in September
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site.

title: Mueller Has Early Draft of Trump Letter Giving Reasons for Firing Comey
description: WASHINGTON  The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has obtained a letter drafted by President Trump and a top political aide that offered an unvarnished view of Mr. Trumps thinking in the days before the president fired the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey.

title: Amy Beach, a Pioneering American Composer, Turns 150
description: Shortly after Antonin Dvorak arrived in the United States in 1892, for a historic visit that resulted in the creation of his New World Symphony, he made a cursory remark to a Boston newspaper about gender and the field of music.

title: Janine Charrat, Ballerina and Choreographer, Dies at 93
description: Janine Charrat, a noted French ballerina who became a major choreographer at a time when few women were engaged in that pursuit and survived a midcareer accident that left her badly burned, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 93.

title: Is There a Date-Stamp on the Moving Body?
description: A work by Monica Bill Barnes warrants certain expectations. It will be humorous, it will be fun and, despite your cynical self, you will laugh.

title: Blunting the Far Right, Merkel Gains as German Election Nears
description: ANNABERG-BUCHHOLZ, Germany  Taking the stage, Chancellor Angela Merkel thanked the thousands of Germans who had turned out at a recent campaign rally, and then leveled her gaze at a small but noisy knot of right-wing protesters yelling and blowing whistles at the back of the square.

title: Review: Tulip Fever Delivers a Wilted Period Piece
description: Theres no way around reviewing Tulip Fever without noting that the movie has been buried deeper than a tulip bulb. The Vulture writer Kyle Buchanan has already provided a rundown of the substantial delays in the films release, which  for a project once regarded as an Oscar contender  might be taken as a sign of an odor other than floral. This week, Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of the Weinstein Company, the films distributor, took the extraordinary step of defending the movie in advance with a column for Deadline Hollywood, though it is laced with passive-aggressive barbs like I know this films not perfect, very few are, but its a perfectly good time in a movie theater.

title: My Son, Off to College
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasio Says Donors Were Denied Favors. How Many? Hard to Say.
description: Dogged by investigations into his political fund-raising, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised last year to prove his integrity to New Yorkers by providing concrete examples of campaign contributors who did not get favors from his administration.

title: Hurricane Irma Looms, but Its Too Early to Predict Landfall
description: A week after Hurricane Harvey made landfall in Texas, another powerful storm system is looming. But forecasters say it is too early to determine where Hurricane Irma, a Category 3 storm with 115-mile-per-hour winds that was moving west in the Atlantic Ocean early on Friday, would have any impact on land, if at all.

title: Chinese Firm With Big Stake in Lenovo to Buy Control of Luxembourg Bank
description: LONDON  Legend Holdings, the Chinese company that is the computer manufacturer Lenovo Groups largest shareholder, said on Friday that it had agreed to buy a 90 percent stake in Banque Internationale  Luxembourg for 1.48 billion euros, or about $1.75 billion.

title: The Looming Uncertainty for Dreamers Like Me
description: Tuesday was my first day back at school at Baruch College for my senior year. I had been looking forward to starting class again, but it was impossible to pay attention. I was completely distracted by the whiplash of news about whether Donald Trump would end the executive order Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA,  the policy President Barack Obama announced in 2012 that allowed almost 800,000 immigrant youths like me to step out of the shadows of society.

title: In Election Interference, Its What Reporters Didnt Find That Matters
description: The story started, as many do, with our own confusion.

title: What to Read About Hurricane Harvey
description: As people begin to comprehend the scope of Hurricane Harveys destruction and to plot a path forward, we collected some of the best coverage from around the internet.

title: An American Abroad
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Whats Driving Job Growth in Industrial America?
description: President Trump campaigned on reviving the kinds of jobs done in factories, coal mines and oil fields. Since he took office, hiring has indeed ticked upward in these sectors, but is there any connection?

title: Lil Uzi Vert and a Generation of Rap Stars Looking Beyond Hip-Hop
description: Listen to hip-hop in 2017 and hear the darnedest things. There are rappers who rap in only occasional, seemingly random bursts. There are rappers who mainline the aesthetic and vibrating energy of punk. And there are surrealists who stretch out words and melodies like taffy.

title: The Yankees Judges Chambers: A Promotion to Dismiss?
description: There was a game Thursday night when the Yankees marketing ploy suddenly was golden; when a real Supreme Court justice, Sonia Sotomayor, donned a black robe and sat in the Judges Chambers at the Bronx stadium to cheer on Aaron Judge.

title: Better Planning for Inevitable Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Hurricane Harvey: Only One Recent Storm Comes Close
description: Comparing more than 200 billion-dollar natural disasters since 1980.

title: Rocks Not Dead, Its Ruled by Women: The Round-Table Conversation
description: For years now, we, the pop music team of The New York Times  Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz and Jon Pareles  have wondered where exactly the guitars went. While theres never been a shortage of quote-unquote traditional rock bands  say, a mostly male, mostly white four-piece  their cultural impact has continued to wane in the face of increasingly diverse musical tactics, distribution networks and messengers.

title: Vanguard Speaks Softly but Carries a Big Stick
description: The activist hedge-fund manager Paul Singer recently warned that the rise of so-called passive investing risked distorting markets and devouring capitalism.

title: If Not for The Jinx, Robert Durst May Have Avoided Murder Charges
description: Robert A. Dursts Los Angeles trial for the murder of his friend Susan Berman is still a year away. But for the last seven months, testimony in a series of conditional hearings has battered Mr. Durst, the eccentric scion of a New York real estate family. Despite his frail demeanor, witnesses have testified, over the years he has had episodes of violence, and often a revolver in his possession.

title: Amid Allegations, a Call for Essex County Colleges Board to Resign
description: NEWARK  A group of New Jersey religious leaders called for the resignation of the entire board of Essex County College Thursday and for federal and state investigations into allegations of financial malfeasance and undue political influence at the institution, which is in danger of losing its accreditation after years of mismanagement.

title: Pope Francis Sought Psychoanalysis at 42, According to Book
description: ROME  At 42, Pope Francis had weekly sessions with a psychoanalyst for about six months to clarify some things, according to excerpts from a new book by a French sociologist scheduled to be published next week.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: The latest side project from the popular American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin involves real-time motion sensors; costumes by Dior; and projections by his father, Dmitrij, also an accomplished ballet dancer. A commission by the Works & Process Rotunda Project, this 30-minute work  scheduled to be performed twice nightly, at 8 and 9:30 p.m., on Monday and Tuesday  features Mr. Simkin, the Ballet Theater soloist Cassandra Trenary, the Hubbard Street dancer Ana Lopez and Brett Conway in juicy choreography by the Hubbard Street house choreographer, Alejandro Cerrudo. With observers watching from above, standing along the Guggenheims spiraling ramps, the dancers will tangle with each other and their own shadows, which, thanks to technology, will seem to have developed minds of their own. BRIAN SCHAEFER

title: Helping Women Over 50 Face Their Financial Fears
description: Ronni Ginott was at a New Years Day party in 2003 when her husband, David, had a heart attack and died on the spot, at 58.

title: Rome Survived Caligula. Will America Survive Trump?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nashville Statement Is an Attack on L.G.B.T. Christians
description: This week, an influential group of evangelical Christians publicly doubled down on intolerance in a message about lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people that represents a renewed commitment to open bigotry.

title: What if I Bombed at My Own Wedding?
description: Any nerves I had leading up to my wedding manifested less as a case of cold feet than as a flare-up of preshow jitters. There were, of course, the predictable stresses: Did everyone receive their invitations? Will my mothers elderly cousins dance to The Thong Song?

title: Matchesfashion.com Sells Majority Stake to Apax After Fierce Bidding War
description: LONDON  Matchesfashion.com, the British luxury e-commerce group that began life as a single bricks-and-mortar boutique before growing into one of the most powerful online players in the global high-fashion market, has a new majority shareholder after a fierce bidding war.

title: Michael Cromartie, Who Guided Journalists on Religion, Dies at 67
description: Michael Cromartie, who shepherded a generation of journalists toward more informed coverage of religions evolving junction with politics and public policy, died on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 67.

title: Narcos Season 3 Premiere: Life Without Pablo
description: Welcome back, everyone. The last time we checked in on Narcos, Pablo Escobar was bleeding out on a Colombian rooftop. It was the logical (and historically accurate) end to two seasons of drama and violence.

title: Trump Says Decision on Dreamers Program Will Come Soon
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Friday said he would announce a decision by Tuesday on whether he will end the Obama-era program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation, declaring, We love the Dreamers even as his White House grappled with how to wind down their legal status.

title: Dakota Plan to Bury, Not Burn, Scaffold Sculpture
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The remains of Scaffold, a sculpture that prompted outrage among Native Americans this summer when it was placed in the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden, will be buried in a secret location in Minnesota, according to Ron Leith, a Dakota representative.

title: Retrieving Gold, and More, From Wastewater
description: Q. Are the heavy metals removed from wastewater valuable?

title: Led by a Vietnam War Opus, a Rich Season of Documentaries
description: Watch a lot of television documentaries and docu-series, as I do, and you might have started to feel over the last few years as if a handful of subjects were monopolizing filmmakers attention. Syria. Shootings of black people by police officers. Prison conditions and the plight of ex-convicts. Stress and suicide among military veterans.

title: Polarizing Former New York Detective Will Be Honored by His Peers
description: If they know him at all, most New Yorkers know Louis Scarcella as the once-renowned and now retired detective whose reputation for solving murders has been battered in recent years by serial allegations of misconduct.

title: Turkeys President Calls U.S. Indictments of His Guards a Scandal
description: Turkeys president denounced what he called the scandalous American judicial system on Friday, responding to new indictments of his bodyguards over a brawl during his visit to Washington in May.

title: For Car Buyers, Larger Inventories May Mean Good Deals
description: The end of summer is often a good time to find deals on new car purchases  and that is especially true this year, given that car sales have slowed and dealers are eager to make sales.

title: New America, a Google-Funded Think Tank, Faces Backlash for Firing a Google Critic
description: WASHINGTON  The head of an influential think tank funded by Google is grappling with a mounting backlash  including from her own scholars and donors  over the firing of a leading critic of the tech giant.

title: What 8 Art Fans Wore to a Hamptons Opening
description: Auto Body, a scrappy artist collective in Bellport, N.Y., unveiled a new exhibition this summer. Commissioned by the Parrish Art Museum, the works include cheeky road signs like Hold Your Horses and Takes Two to Canoe, erected along the traffic-clogged stretch of Montauk Highway between Bellport and Water Mill. To celebrate the project, artists, weekenders and others gathered on Aug. 12 at Bush Farms and Museum.

title: Louise Hay, Widely Read Self-Help Author, Dies at 90
description: Louise Hay, who from a 1984 best seller built a self-help publishing empire that has attracted millions of devotees with its messages about the power of thought and attitude, died on Wednesday at her home in San Diego. She was 90.

title: Cowboys Elliott and Players Union Sue to Void Any Suspension
description: Less than a week before the N.F.L. season begins, the league and one its most prominent players, Ezekiel Elliott of the Dallas Cowboys, have set the stage for a down-to-the-wire court battle over his six-game suspension related to a domestic violence incident.

title: The Playlist: U2 Dances Into Darkness and 11 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, N.O.R.E. and Pharrell Williams team up again, tributes to Thelonious Monk start to pour in, and Robert Plant unleashes a dark vision.

title: Juicero, Start-Up With a $700 Juicer and Top Investors, Shuts Down
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  From the moment it started, Juicero stood out as a symbol of Silicon Valleys insular excess.

title: White House to Ask for $14.5 Billion Down Payment for Harvey Relief
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is asking Congress for more than $14 billion as a down payment on Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts, sending Republican leaders a request late Friday for $7.8 billion in immediate aid that will be quickly followed by a request for another $6.7 billion, officials said.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: A Taste of Indian Nostalgia Finds an Eager Audience
description: EDISON, N.J.  For anyone who grew up in India during the second half of the 20th century, ice cream is inseparable from the name Kwality.

title: Canada Letter: Debating Sir John A. and a Remote Town Stranded
description: The legacy of Sir John A. Macdonald, the first prime minister of Canada, has become the subject of debate in light of his attitudes and policies toward indigenous people. Kingston, Ontario, seemed like the obvious place to go to explore the issue. Macdonald grew up there, represented it in Parliament until his death in 1891 and is buried there.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Alexandr Dolgopolov Wins, but Is Grilled About a Suspicious Loss
description: A dozen reporters crowded around a small table Wednesday afternoon to talk to Alexandr Dolgopolov after his five-set victory over Jan-Lennard Struff in the first round of the United States Open.

title: Astros, Best in A.L., Bulk Up Pitching by Acquiring Verlander
description: The Houston Astros reported to spring training believing they were the best team in the American League. They have proved it ever since, arriving in September with the A.L.s best record, at 80-53. But even in March, their starting rotation seemed thin. Jeff Luhnow, their general manager, had been unwilling  not unable  to trade for an ace last winter.

title: See Harveys Path From a Helicopter
description: Get a 360-degree view of the flooding and damage caused by Tropical Storm Harvey in and around Houston and Port Arthur, Tex.

title: Texas, Russia, Uhuru Kenyatta: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Karoly Makk, Acclaimed Hungarian Filmmaker, Dies at 91
description: Karoly Makk, a leading Hungarian director who was honored at the Cannes Film Festival in 1971 for Love, the story of one familys survival under his countrys repressive Stalinist rule, then nominated four years later for an Academy Award for best foreign-language film, for  Cats Play, died on Aug. 30. He was 91.

title: Handling of Police Killing Spurs Grand Jury Inquiry Into Prosecutor
description: ALBANY  The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, intends to impanel a grand jury this month to investigate a district attorney in relation to the fatal police shooting in Troy, N.Y., of an unarmed motorist in 2016.

title: Serena Williams Gives Birth to a Baby Girl
description: Serena Williams has given birth to a girl, according to the United States Opens official Twitter account and her coach.

title: Judge Throws Out Most Serious Charges in Penn State Hazing Case
description: A Pennsylvania judge on Friday dismissed the most serious charges against eight Penn State fraternity members indicted in the hazing death of a 19-year-old student, sharply and suddenly defanging prosecutors and setting the stage for a new legal battle in the high-profile case.

title: Data Shows Mayweather-McGregor Was a Pay-Per-View Juggernaut
description: The blockbuster fight between the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. and the mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor last Saturday has a very good shot at being the top-grossing fighting event of all time, the Showtime Sports executive in charge of it said Friday.

title: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso, Die Young
description: No column today, and radio silence, because Im traveling (forum at Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, talking Trump and NAFTA). But I have time for a quick entry  this live version (with a Mountain Man reunion!) has been going around my brain for days.

title: A Long-Pursued ISIS Preacher Is Finally Charged in New York
description: WASHINGTON  For two decades, Abdullah el-Faisal has preached jihad, on the streets and online, first promoting the grim theology of Al Qaeda and then endorsing the Islamic State. Imprisoned in England and later deported from Kenya to his native Jamaica, he has in recent years kept up his internet proselytizing from his home near Kingston. His influence has turned up repeatedly in major terrorism cases.

title: Forceful Chief of Staff Grates on Trump, and the Feeling Is Mutual
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump was in an especially ornery mood after staff members gently suggested he refrain from injecting politics into day-to-day issues of governing after last months raucous rally in Arizona, and he responded by lashing out at the most senior aide in his presence.

title: Jim Rice Weighs In on C.C. Sabathia-Eduardo Nunez Feud
description: In the annals of the sometimes ferocious Yankees-Boston Red Sox rivalry, there have been some memorable matchups and more than a few brawls.

title: Stranded ISIS Convoy Symbolizes Militants Stalled Campaign
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Islamic State militant, his AK-47 cradled between his legs, crouched next to the driver in the front of the bus, near a placard in the windshield that read B-9, which stood for bus No. 9 out of 17. The flash of a camera in the early dawn light showed him to be smiling broadly.

title: Tal Afar After Liberation From ISIS: Battered but Still Standing
description: TAL AFAR, Iraq  An airstrike left a crater the size of a tennis court in one neighborhood. Artillery punched a gaping hole in the minaret of the citys main mosque. Some buildings were leveled.

title: A Turning Point for South Vietnam?
description: Tomorrow marks the 50th anniversary of Vietnams most democratic election.

title: The Older the Better in Professional Tennis These Days
description: The future of mens tennis has appeared to be previewing itself during the first week at the United States Open. Just how far into the future is anyones guess.

title: For Vulnerable Older Adults, a Harrowing Sense of Being Trapped
description: HOUSTON  A Holocaust survivor waded waist-deep in flood water. Dozens of people were trapped in a 14-story residence for seniors. A disabled man sat alone at home, without the aide who usually helps him, watching the water rise and unsure if anyone would come.

title: Waiting for a Perfect Protest?
description: Media outlets and commentators representing a range of political persuasions have called attention to recent outbreaks of violence in Berkeley, Calif., Boston and other locations where anti-racist and anti-fascist demonstrators have gathered. Intentionally or not, they have often promoted a false equivalency between groups that advocate white supremacy and those that seek to eliminate it.

title: Venus Williams, a Newly Minted Aunt, Keeps Her Focus on the Business at Hand
description: The news came before Venus Williams stepped onto the court for her third-round match Friday afternoon at the United States Open. Big news, about her sister Serena.

title: Where Harvey Hit Hardest Up and Down the Texas Coast
description: Over 150,000 properties in Texas have been affected by Hurricane Harvey, based on preliminary estimates by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Quotation of the Day: Little Effort to Investigate in States Targeted by Election Hacking
description: We dont know if any of the problems were an accident, or the random problems you get with computer systems, or whether it was a local hacker, or actual malfeasance by a sovereign nation-state.

title: Water Damage From Hurricane Harvey Extended Far Beyond Flood Zones
description: About 40 percent of flooded buildings were in areas considered a minimal flood hazard.

title: Denis Shapovalov, 18, Advances to Fourth Round at U.S. Open
description: Denis Shapovalovs high-flying and improbable run at the United States Open continued Friday as he advanced to the fourth round of only his second Grand Slam main-draw event.

title: How to Regulate Artificial Intelligence
description: The technology entrepreneur Elon Musk recently urged the nations governors to regulate artificial intelligence before its too late. Mr. Musk insists that artificial intelligence represents an existential threat to humanity, an alarmist view that confuses A.I. science with science fiction. Nevertheless, even A.I. researchers like me recognize that there are valid concerns about its impact on weapons, jobs and privacy. Its natural to ask whether we should develop A.I. at all.

title: If You Want to MAGA, Save DACA
description: What is it, really, that makes a country great?

title: Corrections: September 2, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Where Theres Smoke, Theres a Conspiracy Theory at a Russian Consulate
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amid rare extreme heat in San Francisco, it was unusual to see black smoke billowing from a chimney on Friday  not to mention that it was coming from the Russian Consulate, the day after the Trump administration ordered it closed.

title: Utah Nurse Handcuffed After Refusing to Draw Patients Blood
description: The body camera video from a Salt Lake City police officer in an emergency room at University of Utah Hospital was rife with tension.

title: In Beaumont, Tex., Hopscotching for Food, Water and Shelter
description: BEAUMONT, Tex.  Carrie Chambliss climbed into her husbands truck on Friday and drove a winding route some 70 miles, plowing through deep water, to get from her home in Mauriceville to a grocery store in Beaumont that had barely anything left.

title: The Second Video Ever Shown on MTV
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Well, this was a lot of fun. Erik Agard is back with a puzzle that not only debuts a whopping 11 entries, but also contains a lot of really good stuff and devious cluing.

title: U.S. Stumbles in Qualifying on Night Mexico Clinches Place in World Cup
description: HARRISON, N.J.  If a sense of inevitability about qualifying for next years World Cup had begun to take hold for the United States national team under Bruce Arena, a feeling that he had reset the teams course since replacing the teams previous coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, that aura vanished Friday night.

title: A Tennis Player Rises in the Rankings After a Terrible Fall
description: On a summer evening six years ago, the Italian tennis player Stefano Travaglia walked from his familys sixth-floor apartment in the town of Ascoli Piceno near the Adriatic coast to the floor below. He needed to pick up some tennis shirts onto which an elderly neighbor had sewn sponsor patches for him. He bypassed the buildings elevator for the short trip, taking the stairs.

title: The Summer of Loves Dispiriting Fall
description: THE Summer of Love began with a burst of flower power. On June 1, 1967, the Beatles released Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band, and the horticulture was nearly as impressive as the music. In the foreground of the album cover, the flowers spelled out the bands name, and formed other shapes nearby  a guitar here, a star there. A daisy grew from Johns shoulder, a natural epaulet.

title: Catcher Derek Norris Suspended for Season Under Domestic Violence Policy
description: The free-agent catcher Derek Norris was suspended Friday for the rest of the season for violating Major League Baseballs domestic violence policy.

title: Eduardo Nunez, Once a Friend to the Yankees, Is Now a Thorn in Their Side
description: During Eduardo Nunezs four seasons as a Yankee, he was part team mascot, part punch line.

title: Maybe Colin Kaepernick Is Just Not That Good
description: Whether or not Colin Kaepernick plays another down in the N.F.L., Im going to say that he can achieve more off a football field than he  or anyone else in the sport  can achieve on one.

title: Primary Choices for the New York City Council
description: Here are endorsements in five competitive races.

title: Seahawks Acquire Sheldon Richardson From the Jets
description: The Seattle Seahawks acquired defensive tackle Sheldon Richardson from the Jets on Friday in exchange for wide receiver Jermaine Kearse and a second-round draft pick, bolstering a defense that was already considered among the best in the N.F.L.

title: A Polished Hotel in Asbury Park Is New Center of Gravity
description: From $125.

title: Man Barred From Open Last Year Is Arrested After Returning
description: The United States Tennis Association announced on Friday the arrest of an Estonian man who violated a no-trespassing order by returning to the United States Open after having been ejected from the tournament last year.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Humans of New York and A Monster Calls
description: Brandon Stantons popular photography project comes to Facebooks new streaming platform. And a family drama about a 12-year-old boy and a monstrous tree arrives on HBO.

title: The First Count of Fentanyl Deaths in 2016: Up 540% in Three Years
description: The first governmental account of nationwide drug deaths in 2016 shows overdose deaths growing even faster than previously thought.

title: In Indonesia, 3 Muslim Girls Fight for Their Right to Play Heavy Metal
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The three teenage girls  shy and even seeming slightly embarrassed as they peer out from their Islamic head scarves  do not look much like a heavy metal band.

title: Town After Town Under Water in the 100 Miles From Houston to Beaumont
description: Hurricane Harvey left residents of many small towns stranded.

title: 'Today We Should Not Be Blue- or Red-State People
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: In Venezuela, Cooking With Firewood as Currency Collapses
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Food shortages were already common in Venezuela, so Tabata Soler knew painfully well how to navigate the countrys black market stalls to get basics like eggs and sugar.

title: Rosa Parks House in Berlin Has a Ticket Home to America
description: LONDON  In a backyard in Berlin, a ramshackle house that was once a haven for the civil rights pioneer Rosa Parks is preparing for its third life  back in the United States.

title: Silicon Valley Courts Brand-Name Teachers, Raising Ethics Issues
description: MAPLETON, N.D.  One of the tech-savviest teachers in the United States teaches third grade here at Mapleton Elementary, a public school with about 100 students in the sparsely populated plains west of Fargo.

title: Dear Sugars: In the Shadow of Damaged Parents
description: Her father had cheated, and her mother blamed herself and the children for his infidelities. She said if we were better behaved and hed had a better home life, he would have never cheated on us, this weeks letter writer recalls. "She told my sister and me that we were not attractive enough to keep a man.

title: Celine Dion Loves You. And You. And You.
description: Annick Chenard, 38, has seen Celine Dion in concert 21 times and also has a large tattoo of Ms. Dions face and flowing hair on her right shoulder. She recently spent a whole day out on a Montreal street with a fold-up chair and a poncho, waiting for a slim chance to meet her queen.

title: EJ Johnson Is Not Just Some Other Rich Girl
description: Today we are talking about breaking boundaries, EJ Johnson declared from the stage of Beautycon, a two-day cosmetics festival held in August at the Los Angeles Convention Center. The 25-year-old son of Magic Johnson was moderating a panel called The Gender Revolution, and he was dressed for the part: black silk pants, crop top, sleeveless duster.

title: Want to Have a Good Day? Try Making the Bed First
description: When Adm. William H. McRaven, retired, was stationed in Afghanistan, his days were filled with chaos and unpredictability. We could have soldiers dying and the horror of civilian casualties, he said.

title: New York City Parks in the Summer: Romance, Games and a Performance for a Dying Tree
description: Parks in New York offer one of the citys most coveted and valuable amenities: space. You very rarely have room to spread out and not think about getting in somebodys way, said Daniel Arnold, a photographer who spent two months capturing moments in New York Citys open spaces. Theres this psychological relief to them.

title: Get Ready for Technological Upheaval by Expecting the Unimagined
description: Self-driving vehicles could upend the transportation sector and eliminate a million or more jobs. Algorithms that decode M.R.I.s put a whole medical subfield at risk. And the list of professions and sectors soon to be obsolete grows steadily by the day.

title: Give Up Prosecco to Save Your Teeth? British Claim Riles Italy
description: ROME  A storm in a wineglass has erupted between Italy and Britain after some British dentists claimed this past week that prosecco, the bubbly North Italian wine, causes chronic tooth decay.

title: Eid al-Adha: Muslims Around the World Celebrate Holy Festival
description: Millions of Muslims across the globe  including in countries like India, Indonesia, Turkey, Russia and Pakistan  are celebrating Eid al-Adha, Islams most revered observance.

title: LOral Drops Transgender Model Over Comments on Race
description: A transgender activist and model was dropped from a LOral ad campaign because of comments she made on social media about race, the company said on Friday.

title: Video of Police Officer Knocking Down Woman and Child Incenses China
description: BEIJING  Twenty-two seconds of real-life police drama have riveted and divided many in China over officers powers to use force against irate residents  including a woman clutching an infant.

title: After Harvey, a Return Home in High Water
description: Days after a storm battered Houston, a family made an emotional return through waist-high water to see their flooded home and collect their belongings.

title: He Had Her at We the People
description: Melissa Rose Alpert and Trevor Douglas Mills are to be married Sept. 3 at Rock Island Lake Club, an events space in Sparta, N.J. Mike Schellhammer, a friend of the groom who is affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, is to officiate.

title: Finding Comfort in Each Other, and the Unknown
description: Kelly Anthoula Love and Hristos George Karavoulias were married Sept. 2 in Lowell, Mass. Rev. Gregory Christakos performed the ceremony at the Transfiguration Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Stranger Than Fiction: What Happened After the Bookstore
description: Molly Higgins Fischer married Samuel Chandler MacLaughlin Sept. 2 in South Dartmouth, Mass. Nina MacLaughlin, the grooms sister, who received a one-day marriage designation from the state of Massachusetts, officiated at the home of the grooms father and his partner, Pamela A. Murray.

title: Human Toll of Harvey Comes Into View as Waters Recede
description: One couple had just another stop or two in their pickup truck, a check on an elderly uncle. A 60-year-old woman had just lain down for a much-needed nap. An 8-year-old boy was riding in a van with his extended family in search of higher ground.

title: One Week After Harvey, Texas Residents Exhausted, Still Stranded
description: HOUSTON  A week after Texas was slammed by Hurricane Harvey, this region was still engulfed in crisis on Saturday, with weary residents of Houston searching for ways to repair swamped homes and salvage possessions even as others faced new orders to evacuate. In cities and small towns to the east, thousands of others remained stranded by rising waters and were still without dry shelter.

title: The Popcast Answers Your Questions About Beyonc, Music Videos and More
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: For One Family in Houston, an Overwhelming Start to Recovery
description: HOUSTON  She couldnt sleep. Not now.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Like our constructors, I no longer own a Magic 8 Ball, but I had one when I was a child. When you are young and innocent and hope against hope for something to come true, you will go to extraordinary lengths to confirm that hope.

title: Police and Protesters Clash Over Disappearance of Argentine Activist
description: BUENOS AIRES  The disappearance of an indigenous rights activist in Argentina spurred violent clashes between demonstrators and the police on Friday and has raised dark memories of forced disappearances during the countrys dictatorship.

title: ISIS Is on Its Heels, but Fighting to the Death
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NIMITZ, in the Persian Gulf  A few days ago, Capt. Mike Spencer of the Navy rocketed off the flight deck of an aircraft carrier in his F-18 to provide air support for Iraqi troops advancing on the dusty city of Tal Afar, one of the Islamic States last strongholds.

title: Minnesota Finds a Way to Slow Soaring Health Premiums
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Last fall, as consumers in Minnesota were facing health insurance rate increases of 50 percent or more, Gov. Mark Dayton, a Democrat, said the Affordable Care Act was no longer affordable to increasing numbers of people. The states top insurance regulator said the Minnesota market was on the verge of collapse.

title: Trump Returns to Texas, With Words of Encouragement and Triumph
