Welles Crowther, 24, a rookie equities trader from Upper Nyack, N.Y., who died in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, became known as the Man in the Red Bandana, for the handkerchief he wore as a protective mask while assuming a rescuers role in the South Tower before it collapsed.

title: Read These 3 Books on Hurricanes

For a better understanding of the people who have lived through similar disasters, here are two books that illuminate their lives and another that explains how to reduce the effect these catastrophes have on communities.

But they may well resurface if elements of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, the law created to curtail accounting fraud, are rolled back as some corporate executives are urging.

Its more of a family gathering, Mr. Skarsgard said. Ive invited all my cousins and uncles, and my sister, who works in event planning, is throwing the after-party. My brother Alexander did the same thing with The Legend of Tarzan last year, so he inspired me.

When Atlanta won the prize for best comedy, he celebrated onstage with an impressively continuous hula-style hip swivel, his stance wide, arms sinuous. His happy dance quickly went viral and became a GIF.

Bristling with cameras, antennas and other sensors, it is one of the most complex and sophisticated spy robots ever set loose in interplanetary space.

title: T Magazine Editors on Things Theyre Into Right Now
description: On a leafy block of Cypress Avenue, which runs parallel to the Los Angeles River in Northeast L.A.s Cypress Park neighborhood, the writer and editor Christie Hayden has opened Oof Books. Hayden, who developed a love for artist-made books while a graduate student at the Maryland Institute College of Art and most recently worked with Hauser & Wirths Book & Printed Matter Lab, found the pocket-size space while searching for an apartment on Craigslist. The idea for a bookshop came together almost immediately. She tapped designers Jonathan Olivares, Paul Matevosyan and Raffy Mardirossian to create simple, bold shelving  painted mustard yellow in a nod to the Ed Ruscha painting from which the shop takes its name  and began sourcing books. Oof specializes in artist-made and locally published books and zines, as well as older catalogs and monographs. Some of Haydens favorite recent finds include Jenny Holzers Truisms and a Fernand Lger that she says, Im definitely going to grieve a bit to sell. The shop also features art objects by ceramist Grant Levy-Lucero and hosts regular work and talks from emerging L.A. artists.   MERRELL HAMBLETON

title: Fox News Ousts Eric Bolling After Probe Into Lewd Text Messages
description: Fox News confirmed Friday that it had ousted the longtime host Eric Bolling and canceled the show he co-hosted about a month after a report that he had sent lewd photographs to three female colleagues via text message.

title: Afghan Anger Simmers Over U.S. Leaflets Seen as Insulting Islam
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The sermon at the mosque in Kabuls diplomatic quarter on Friday sounded a familiar but disquieting theme.

title: Conservationists See a Hurricane Risk: Floridas Exotic Pets Could Escape
description: When Hurricane Andrew battered South Florida in 1992, conservationists say, a slithering, voracious species escaped a breeding facility and made its way toward Everglades National Park. There, the Burmese python, originally from Southeast Asia, would feast on raccoons, eggs and deer, multiplying into the tens of thousands, until it had ravaged the ecosystem.

title: Why Common Critiques of DACA Are Misleading
description: Defenders of President Trumps decision to rescind an Obama-era immigration policy that shielded young immigrants from deportation have offered misleading critiques of the program.

title: Bridgewaters Ray Dalio Spreads His Gospel of Radical Transparency
description: As thousands of Egyptians took to the streets during the Arab Spring protests of 2011, Ray Dalio, a hedge fund billionaire, decided to sail the Nile River with some friends, including some other financiers.

title: Monse: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Holger Czukay, 79, Influential Rock Experimenter, Is Dead
description: Holger Czukay, a guiding force in the German experimental rock group Can, one of the most influential bands of the 1970s, died on Tuesday at his home studio in Weilerswist, Germany. He was 79.

title: Two Hurricanes in Two Weeks Bring Two Very Different Reactions
description: WEST KENDALL, Fla.  In the psychology of evacuations, what Hurricane Katrina was to Rita in 2005, so Harvey has been to Irma today.

title: Troy Gentry of the Country Music Duo Montgomery Gentry Dies at 50
description: Troy Gentry, who was part of the popular country music duo Montgomery Gentry, was killed on Friday in a helicopter crash in Medford, N.J., where the group was to play that night. He was 50.

title: Mercurial Trump Rattles Republican Party Ahead of Midterms
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps mercurial politics are already rattling Republicans heading into the 2018 midterm campaign, sparking Trump-like primary challenges in two high-profile Senate races and a host of lower-profile House contests, while pushing a growing number of moderate House members to the exits.

title: 'We Shall Overcome Verse Not Under Copyright, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge on Friday struck down the copyright for part of the civil rights anthem We Shall Overcome, saying that the songs adaptation from an older work  including changing will to shall  was not original enough to qualify for protection.

title: Jim McDaniels, 69, Dies; Led Western Kentucky to Final Four
description: Jim McDaniels, a star center who led Western Kentucky University to the N.C.A.A. Final Four but whose professional career was marred by contract disputes at the start, died on Wednesday in Bowling Green, Ky. He was 69.

title: Next Stop for the Steve Bannon Insurgency: China
description: WASHINGTON  Stephen K. Bannon has held court in the Capitol Hill townhouse of Breitbart Media since he packed up his West Wing office last month, meeting with conservative lawmakers, advocating hard-line policies on undocumented immigrants and waging gleeful war on those he considers traitors to the Trump cause.

title: The Lungs of Our Region Are on Fire: Wildfires Exact a Punishing Toll on the West
description: For much of this week and last, devastation wrought by Hurricane Harvey in Houston and Hurricane Irma in the Caribbean has grabbed front-page headlines. But wildfires in the West have been wreaking destruction of their own, though it has attracted less attention. Vast swaths of land have burned, choking the air with ash and smoke.

title: Hurricane Irma Barrels Toward U.S., Threatening to Engulf Florida
description: MIAMI  This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to Saturdays live Irma updates.

title: The Arts This Fall, in 42 Articles and 80,837 Words
description: Sundays issue of The New York Times is sure to be one of the single heaviest your newspaper carrier will ever deliver. Inside, the Arts & Leisure fall preview issue  all three parts, 42 articles, 80,837 words and 1.9 pounds of it  is independently the largest section produced by Times journalists each year.

title: Pope Sees Two Slain Clerics as Martyrs for Peace in Colombia
description: VILLAVICENCIO, Colombia  Pope Francis acknowledged the scars of Colombias civil conflict on the Roman Catholic Church on Friday, honoring two clerics in the country who were murdered during the war.

title: Rafael Nadal and Kevin Anderson Advance to U.S. Open Final
description: One by one, over the course of several weeks, the top male tennis players dropped out of the United States Open because of injuries.

title: Hurricane Irma Forces Yankees to Play Tampa Bay Rays at Citi Field
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As the Yankees try to chase down the Boston Red Sox during the final weeks of the season, they were handed an advantage on Friday  not by an Apple Watch, but by Hurricane Irma.

title: Quotation of the Day: A Search for Reason in Natures Chaos
description: For so many years, talking about the weather was talking about nothing. Now it really is our survival.

title: How to Help Hurricane Irma Victims
description: As Hurricane Irma roars over the Florida Keys after causing destruction in the Caribbean, here is a guide to how you can help the people it affects.

title: Betsy DeVos Ends a Campus Witch Hunt
description: Suppose youre the kind of thoughtful liberal who concluded from Donald Trumps election that youve been living in a bubble and need to better understand the causes of Americas distemper. Suppose, too, that you have friends who voted for Trump  and who you know for a fact are neither bigots nor buffoons.

title: Anguilla, Reeling From Irma While Readying for Jose
description: Business owners and other officials in Anguilla braced for the second hurricane this week amid the destruction of Irma.

title: Brandon Maxwell: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Republicans Chew Gum. Walk? Not So Much.
description: Tough times, concerned citizens.

title: Something Soon to Happen
description: SATURDAY CROSSWORD  A themeless puzzle has fewer and longer words than a themed one. A 15 by 15 (daily sized) crossword can have a maximum of 78 entries on Monday through Thursday, but only 72 on Friday or Saturday. [This can vary depending on the entertainment value of an individual puzzle and is at the discretion of the editors.  D.A.] Its one way the challenging nature of these wide-open puzzles is engineered in.

title: Corrections: September 9, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Russias Fake Americans
description: It is commonly believed that Russias interference in the 2016 presidential campaign consisted mainly of the hacking and leaking of Democratic emails and unfavorable stories circulated abroad about Hillary Clinton. But as a startling investigation by Scott Shane of The New York Times, and new research by the cybersecurity firm FireEye, now reveal, the Kremlins stealth intrusion into the election was far broader and more complex, involving a cyberarmy of bloggers posing as Americans and spreading propaganda and disinformation to an American electorate on Facebook, Twitter and other platforms.

title: Liberty on His Mind, Doubles Champion Seizes Opportunity at the Mike
description: After Jean-Julien Rojer won his second Grand Slam mens doubles title on Friday, a question about his Statue of Liberty shirt seemed obvious and innocuous.

title: Federal Judge Halts Ezekiel Elliotts Suspension
description: The Dallas Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliott will likely play several games, if not the whole season, after a federal judge Friday issued an injunction halting his suspension for a domestic abuse accusation.

title: Hungary Is Making Europes Migrant Crisis Worse
description: Another summer has passed, and still there seems to be no lasting solution to one of the great humanitarian conundrums of our time: how to resettle the thousands of migrants who continue to risk dangerous passage across the Mediterranean in search of sanctuary from violence in the Middle East and Africa. The number of arrivals in Greece has steadily declined since 2015, after measures that all but closed the route from Turkey. But the problem will remain so long as conflict and poverty drive people to take huge risks in the hope of reaching Europe.

title: Facebook Wins, Democracy Loses
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  On Wednesday, Facebook revealed that hundreds of Russia-based accounts had run anti-Hillary Clinton ads precisely aimed at Facebook users whose demographic profiles implied a vulnerability to political propaganda. It will take time to prove whether the account owners had any relationship with the Russian government, but one thing is clear: Facebook has contributed to, and profited from, the erosion of democratic norms in the United States and elsewhere.

title: Where Theres Fire, Theres Smoke
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  This was the summer that the forests turned red. From the fir and hemlock stands of Puget Sound to the oak and pine groves of California, the light in the woods has gone all kinds of wrong. The greens have been replaced by oranges, the normal hues vaporized in the smoke that has choked so much of the West in this season of wildfire.

title: The Cold Warrior Who Never Apologized
description: As Gen. H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, wrote in his book Dereliction of Duty, the early stages of the Vietnam War caught Americas military leaders flat-footed. Having gone through World War II and Korea, they were all ready for a conventional war. But insurgencies and unconventional warfare were something else. As a result, they were inordinately acquiescent to the wishful thinking of their civilian overseers  and no one thought more wishfully about the war than Walt Whitman Rostow.

title: Jeremy Scott: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Hurricane Irma Is One of the Strongest Storms In History
description: The hurricane has broken records for wind speed and number of days as a Category 5 storm.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Hidden Figures and Portlandia
description: The tale of three bold African-American women who made NASA history arrives on HBO. And Season 7 of Portlandia comes to Netflix.

title: Amazon Eclipse Glasses Lawsuit
description: Corey Payne did not see that the glasses he purchased, and gave to his fiance, were recalled by Amazon because he purchased them through his aunt's account.

title: Europtics Eclipse Glasses Lawsuit
description: A couple in Colorado has accused an eyeglasses chain of providing them with counterfeit glasses, which they say damaged their eyes.

title: Belgian Clubs and Foreign Money: A Modern Soccer Mix
description: TUBIZE, Belgium  There is something incongruous about the pregame razzmatazz at the Stade Leburton, about Michael Buffers catchphrase  Lets get ready to rumble!  crackling out of the loudspeakers, and the pulsing, earsplitting techno soundtrack that follows.

title: Yankees Squander an Opportunity in Texas
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Yankees right fielder Aaron Judge tracked a fly ball down the right-field line that drifted into the stands, he misjudged how far he was from the wall and hit his head against it.

title: Can a Giant Science Fair Transform Kazakhstans Economy?
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  By day, the huge and gleaming sphere looks like the spaceship of aliens who may not have come in peace. At night, it blinks out a playful pattern of colors and boosterish slogans on its high-tech outer skin  a few parts light show, a few parts bumper sticker.

title: Bleak Refuge for Rohingya at Bangladesh Camps
description: A new wave of violence in Rakhine State in western Myanmar has caused 270,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee to Bangladesh. Many Rohingya end up in limbo in a series of refugee camps near the Cox's Bazar area.

title: For Iraqs Long-Suffering Kurds, Independence Beckons
description: BARZAN, Iraq  A pair of rusted eyeglasses, a grimy antique watch, torn bank notes and old identification cards.

title: Dear Amazon, We Picked Your New Headquarters for You
description: Lets skip the nationwide bidding war and cut right to the winner.

title: Legal Marijuana Is Almost Here. If Only Pot Farmers Were on Board.
description: LAYTONVILLE, Calif.  From the sky they look like citrus groves, neat rows of lush emerald-colored plants set amid the hills of Northern California.

title: Vetting an Apartment Before You Buy
description: Q. How do I investigate an apartment, its history and potential problems, before I buy it? Is there a way to determine if the neighbors are noisy, disruptive or have problems with hygiene, like hoarding? Can I test for environmental issues like mold or, in my case, cat dander? Is it possible to find out if the apartment ever had an infestation of bedbugs or other vermin? What about crime in the building? How would I know if the building has ever been reported to the city?

title: We Are Not Criminals, We Are Prisoners
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: Storm Gains Strength as It Nears Florida
description: Read the latest with Sundays live updates on Hurricane Irma.

title: Frustrated Survivors of Grenfell Fire Ask, When Will We Get Our Lives Back?
description: LONDON  It has been almost three months since the inferno that tore through Grenfell Tower, a public housing complex, killing at least 80 people and leaving hundreds more homeless. Yet, in that time, only 24 households out of 158 have been placed in permanent housing.

title: Ralph Lauren Is Still Behind the Wheel
description: I didnt have a bike growing up, Ralph Lauren said one recent afternoon, referring to his modest middle-class boyhood on Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx.

title: Helmut Lang Returns! Or Does He?
description: In fashion, where hysteria is the dominant mode of expression and praise is often ladled out in heaps rather than spoonfuls, coronations can be instantaneous, new gods and icons minted every season. And then there is Helmut Lang.

title: Dear Sugars: Sexless Relationships
description: Erotic intimacy often wanes in long-term monogamous relationships, but its especially confusing when your partner remains loving and affectionate. In this weeks episode, a letter writer who calls herself About to Burst, writes about the dual pain of emotional and physical stonewalling.

title: A Chicago Restaurant With an Impressive Pedigree and a Nordic Soul
description: Chicago is home to many pricey temples of fine dining (Alinea, Oriole, Grace, et al), but chefs Anna and David Posey wanted to create an alternative to the overly formal, often dauntingly expensive prix fixe experience. We both like very fancy things, but we like going about them casually, Mr. Posey said. The result is Elske, which opened in December in the restaurant-rich West Loop, offering a relatively affordable tasting menu ($85) and  la carte options that nimbly blend Midwestern and Nordic sensibilities.

title: Youth in San Diego: Skateboards, Beach Hangs and Chicano Culture
description: San Diego is credited as one of the birthplaces of skateboarding. The sport took hold there in the 1950s, serving as an alternative to surfing when there were no waves. Today, locals see the skateboard as a logistical form of transportation but also a style accessory, the photographer John Francis Peters, who has been living there on and off for five years, said.

title: Shades of Noir: My Hunt for an Eclipse Glasses Villain
description: Earlier this week, a couple in Colorado filed a class-action lawsuit against an eyewear chain they say gave them faulty eclipse glasses. Watching the moons spectacular crossing of the sun on Aug. 21 left them with distorted vision, according to their lawyer. A couple in South Carolina filed a similar lawsuit against Amazon in late August.

title: Ian Buruma on a New Era at The New York Review of Books
description: Some shoes are harder to fill than others. Robert Silvers, the editor synonymous with The New York Review of Books, ran the left-leaning intellectual magazine with single-minded fervor from the time he co-founded it in 1963 until he died at 87 in March. His shoes may as well be Shaquille ONeals.

title: Slovak Village Prospers in Partnership With Roma Residents It Once Shunned
description: SPISSKY HRHOV, Slovakia  In a part of eastern Slovakia where other villages are withering, Spissky Hrhov shows signs of surprising prosperity. The houses are solid and well-tended. There is running water and electricity. A former distillery has been turned into an art space, its facade decorated with a colorful mosaic.

title: Trump Monitors Hurricane as His Cabinet Descends on Camp David
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump monitored the impact of Hurricane Irma from the presidential retreat at Camp David on Saturday as he held the fourth full cabinet meeting of his presidency to discuss how to advance his administrations priorities during the balance of his first year in office.

title: Introducing the Next New York Times iPad App
description: We are pleased to unveil a completely redesigned New York Times app for your iPad. To get the new version, go to the App Store and download it. Tap here and then hit the GET button.

title: The Paranoid Style In Conservative Politics
description: Lots of people are having fun with Rush Limbaughs insistence that warnings about Irma were a liberal plot, part of the great conspiracy to scare people about climate change  plus a sales gimmick for batteries and bottled water. (He evacuated his Palm Beach mansion soon afterwards.)

title: Hurricane Irma in Pictures
description: Irma churned north into Georgia on Monday as a tropical storm, after lashing Florida with hurricane-force winds and pummeling islands in the Caribbean.

title: Refugee Youths Build Community in an Embracing Space
description: Riotous applause and boisterous chanting escorted Mukamil Bakhski, 16, onto the auditorium stage. He had previously sung only in the shower, never before a large crowd, and conquering his nerves was as high a priority as his performance.

title: He Dropped a Plate. She Was Charmed.
description: Molly Elizabeth Matles and Paul Alperin Whiteman are to be married Sept. 10. Rabbi Myra Soifer is to officiate at St. Marys College of California in Moraga, Calif.

title: He Loves Her Spirit, Energy, Laugh, and Her Daughter
description: Sophia Szu-Pei Tang and Steven Louis DeLuca were married Sept. 9 at the Yale Club in Manhattan. Dr. Louis DeLuca, an uncle of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Drone Footage Shows Desolate Miami Beach as Hurricane Irma Nears
description: Normally a tourist hotspot bustling with activity, Miami Beach was all but abandoned Friday evening as Hurricane Irma approached.

title: U.S. Students in Florence Accuse Police Officers of Rape
description: ROME  The Italian authorities are investigating accusations by two American women studying abroad in Florence that they were raped on Thursday by two uniformed members of Italys Carabinieri police force, and Italys defense minister said there appeared to be some basis to the allegations.

title: Leveled Mexican Town Digs for Survivors. Can You Tell Me if My Dads O.K.?
description: JUCHITN DE ZARAGOZA, Mexico  Under the glare of portable floodlights and the flashlights that some held, men in sweat-soaked jumpsuits dug into a hillock of rubble in this town, the night after the largest earthquake to hit Mexico in a century flattened buildings here and across southern Mexico.

title: Data Breach Victims Talk of Initial Terror, Then Vigilance
description: One man said his name had been used to set up a fraudulent company that processed payments made with stolen credit cards. A woman said her bank had told her she was being sought by a collections agency  her Social Security number had been used to open a wireless account that was never paid off.

title: Trumps Bid to End Saudi-Qatar Stalemate Ends in Recriminations
description: CAIRO  An attempt by President Trump to break the stalemate that has divided the wealthiest countries in the Middle East ended in failure on Saturday, when leaders from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, after speaking by phone for the first time in months, exchanged dueling, contradictory statements.

title: The Prayer Circle: Texans Rebuild After Harvey as a Practice of Faith
description: In the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Today we have another Puns and Anagrams crossword (or PandA) from Mel Taub. PandAs are a sort of hybrid between British cryptic puzzles and regular American crosswords. Cryptic purists will disagree with this description. They see PandAs as undisciplined imitations of the real thing, but I dont think its that simple.

title: Death Toll Climbs, and Relief Efforts Stall, as Caribbean Braces for Hurricane Jose
description: POINTE--PITRE, Guadeloupe  As communications started to be restored to the storm-ravaged islands of the Caribbean, five deaths were reported from the British Virgin Islands, raising the toll across the Caribbean to 25 people as the islands braced for yet another storm set to strike as early as Saturday afternoon.

title: Being Like Mike: The Indians Corey Kluber Makes Winning Look Easy
description: On the bench during a recent Cleveland Indians game, the pitching coach Mickey Callaway thought of a thoroughly incongruous comparison: Corey Kluber and Michael Jordan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Extended Rallies in Tennis Can Be a Boost, or a Backbreaker
description: On the scoreboard, every point is worth the same amount, as is every game. But on the court, its a different story.

title: For Rafael Nadal and His Uncle Toni, the Coaching Never Ends
description: Midnight was approaching on Friday. Rafael Nadal was safely back in a United States Open final after wearing down the dangerous Juan Martn del Potro, and the next generation of Nadals was eager to get back on the court.

title: Marching to a Second Term, de Blasio Faces a Diminished Mayoralty
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio should be at the peak of his powers. Crime is down. The economy is up. He has scared away his most serious possible challengers this election year.

title: Nicki Minaj, the Weeknd, Raf Simons and Paris Jackson Partied Last Night at Fashion Week
description: Friday night of New York Fashion Week included parties for Harpers Bazaar, Calvin Klein and The Daily Front Row.

title: Airlines Face Criticism Amid Irma Price-Gouging Complaints
description: Amid complaints of airlines taking advantage of those trying to flee Hurricane Irma, Senators Richard Blumenthal and Edward J. Markey have written to Transportation Secretary Elaine L. Chao, asking her to look into reports of possible price gouging.

title: Bound to No Party, Trump Upends 150 Years of Two-Party Rule
description: WASHINGTON  When Donald J. Trump set his sights on the presidency in the 2000 election, he pursued the nomination of the Reform Party, a home for disenchanted independents. The Republican Party has just moved too far to the extreme right, he explained. The Democrats are too far to the left.

title: Irmas Fearsome Winds Reach Florida Shores, With Full Strike Yet to Come
description: MIAMI  Read the latest with Saturdays live updates on Hurricane Irma.

title: Paraplegic Girl Attacked by Rats in France, Spurring an Investigation
description: PARIS  A 14-year-old girl, described as a paraplegic by her father, was so badly bitten by rats as she slept one night this month that her family says she was bleeding from her ears as well as her fingers, toes and much of her body.

title: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: A Nobel Peace Prize Winners Shame
description: Aung San Suu Kyi, a beloved Nobel Peace Prize winner, is presiding over an ethnic cleansing in Myanmar.

title: As China Moves In, Serbia Reaps Benefits, With Strings Attached
description: SMEDEREVO, Serbia  When President Xi Jinping of China chose an industrial town on the Danube River to announce that Serbia was at the center of a $900 billion One Belt, One Road infrastructure initiative, it was a bold declaration that his country had set up shop on Europes southeastern flank.

title: In Kenya, Will the Peace Hold?
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Peace means so much more after youve experienced violence. Less than a month ago, my country, Kenya, held a hotly contested presidential election. On the morning the polls opened, my heart raced  I come from and work in the Kibera slums, and it is often said, When Kibera burns, so does Kenya. But not this time.

title: The Trump Fever Never Breaks
description: In the first year of his presidency, Donald Trump has achieved at least three things that few presidents ever have. His approval rating is in the 30s. His former aides  and reportedly the president himself  are under federal investigation. And members of Mr. Trumps own party are running what has been described as a shadow campaign to replace him in 2020.

title: Move Over DiCaprio and da Vinci  Heres Irelands Leo
description: DUBLIN  It was a true Irish honeymoon  short and judgmental.

title: Dreamers Put Their Trust in DACA. What Now?
description: Past the Ferris wheel, a line of young immigrants snaked into the crowded hallways of an event space on Chicagos Navy Pier. It was August 2012. I overheard two women wondering whether they should have showed up and gotten in the line, to apply for a new program that would let some undocumented people who had come to this country as children get a work permit.

title: Ex-Inmate Takes to Hong Kongs Airwaves, and Prisoners Tune In
description: HONG KONG  In the tiled corridors of Stanley Prison, a maximum-security complex on a rocky edge of Hong Kongs main island, the chatter among the foreign inmates on Monday mornings tends to revolve around a single question.

title: These Are Not the Robots We Were Promised
description: From the moment we humans first imagined having mechanical servants at our beck and call, weve assumed they would be constructed in our own image. Outfitted with arms and legs, heads and torsos, they would perform everyday tasks that wed otherwise have to do ourselves. Like the indefatigable maid Rosie on The Jetsons, the officious droid C-3PO in Star Wars and the tortured host Dolores Abernathy in Westworld, the robotic helpmates of popular culture have been humanoid in form and function.

title: The Donald Trump Gold Rush
description: Sean Spicer lasted a mere half-year as the White House press secretary, but that was plenty long enough to mortify himself. He began with that kooky, laughable lie about the unprecedented size of President Trumps inauguration crowd, and things didnt pick up much from there. A punching bag for the administration, he became a punch line for much of America.

title: Malaysian Leader, Under Corruption Cloud, Will Meet With Trump
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  For more than a year, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia has been under the cloud of a corruption investigation by the United States Department of Justice. On Tuesday, his scheduled visit to see President Trump at the White House may give him a chance to offset the political damage.

title: The Shape of Water Takes Top Venice Film Festival Prize
description: Guillermo Del Toros The Shape of Water was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 74th Venice International Film Festival by the jury led by Annette Bening. In the film, set in the 1960s, a mute cleaning woman (Sally Hawkins) falls in love with a fishlike hominid in a top-secret laboratory.

title: The Ivanka Way
description: About six months ago, in the long-ago springtime of the Trump presidency, Ivanka Trump made an offer to Cecile Richards, the head of Planned Parenthood. The first daughter had pressed her father to say positive things about Planned Parenthood during the 2016 campaign, and now she had a proposal for the organizations leader: What if Planned Parenthood split up, creating a small operation that ran abortion clinics and a larger one whose health clinics didnt perform abortions? Then her father would call for increasing funding to the larger operation, instead of joining with congressional Republicans in their efforts to defund Planned Parenthood entirely.

title: Loneliness and the College Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Kabul Streets Turn Violent in Annual Reminder of Civil War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In what has become an annual breakdown of law and order, the capital turned into a scene of chaos on Saturday with little visible sign of government control. Young men armed with knives and Kalashnikov rifles sped around Kabul, firing into the air and terrorizing residents, who mostly stayed indoors.

title: Sean McVay, 31, Raced to N.F.L. Pinnacle Faster Than His Counterparts
description: Sean McVay, the first-year coach of the Los Angeles Rams, is the youngest head coach in modern N.F.L. history. Two starters on the teams offensive line are older than him. His defensive coordinator had five seasons of experience in that role before McVay was even born.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit on Care of the Disabled
description: NASHVILLE  A judge on Friday dismissed a longstanding lawsuit over Tennessees treatment of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, ending federal oversight of state programs.

title: Eckhaus Latta: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: How Is President Trumps Business Doing? Check the Electoral College
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C.  Business is booming here at the Trump National Golf Club.

title: President Trumps War on Science
description: The news was hard to digest until one realized it was part of a much larger and increasingly disturbing pattern in the Trump administration. On Aug. 18, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine received an order from the Interior Department that it stop work on what seemed a useful and overdue study of the health risks of mountaintop-removal coal mining.

title: Tyler Austin, Seizing a Rare Opportunity, Delivers a Win for the Yankees
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  After looking at the first pitch from reliever Richard Rodriguez, Tyler Austin stepped out of the batters box to gather himself. He did not need to remind himself that the bases were loaded and the score tied with one out in the ninth inning.

title: Dolphins, Flamingos and Pigs: The Animals Rescued From Hurricane Irma
description: Humans are not the only ones seeking shelter from the strong winds, heavy rains and deadly floods of Hurricane Irma.

title: Sloane Stephens Beats Madison Keys to Claim U.S. Open Title
description: It was springtime in the United States, and the womens tennis tour was in full swing, with the clay-court season underway. Kamau Murray received a call in April from his injured protg Sloane Stephens, who explained that she was ready to start practicing.

title: Off the Runway: Creatures of the Wind, Adam Lippes and More
description: Our photographer caught the action during New York Fashion Week.

title: Well, What Should Hillary Clinton Do Now?
description: Whats to be done with Hillary Clinton, the woman who wont go away?

title: Waiting for the Big One in Florida
description: ABBEVILLE, S.C.  In September 1984, my wife, Susan, and I left Fairfield, Conn., our home for 43 years, and drove south. Wed had enough of New England winters. We stopped 23 hours later in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rented a 450-square-foot apartment on the Intracoastal Waterway a mile from the beach, and began our new life in paradise.

title: Pope Francis Shifts Power From Rome With Hugely Important Liturgical Reform
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis, who has used his absolute authority in the Vatican to decentralize power from Rome, made a widespread change Saturday to the ways, and words, in which Roman Catholics worship by amending Vatican law to give national bishop conferences greater authority in translating liturgical language.

title: Weather Channel Goes Into Overdrive Covering Back-to-Back Hurricanes
description: ATLANTA  At 8:06 on Friday morning, Nora Zimmett had a minor crisis on her hands.

title: Size Matters
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I recently mentioned Brendan Emmett Quigley and his ear for speech (remember the WHY YOU LITTLE entry?). Today, he gives us a phonetically-based crossword.

title: Not Surfing on 9/11
description: A large but widely ignored presence in New York City on the eve of Sept. 11, 2001, was Hurricane Erin, its cyclonic swirl starkly visible in weather maps like an ominous asterisk just off the coast. Two groups noticed: meteorologists, who mentioned the storm in passing, if at all, in news reports; and surfers, who chattered breathlessly about it.

title: A de Kooning, a Theft and an Enduring Mystery
description: Willem de Kooning completed Woman-Ochre in 1955. It depicts a defiantly naked figure facing the viewer, arms akimbo. At the time, de Kooning had a studio in Greenwich Village, where his artistic vision  not to mention his quiet charm and energetic drinking  made him a figure of renown on the art scene.

title: Irma Will Test Floridas Infrastructure, From Dikes to Sewage Plants

title: The Deuce Series Premiere Recap: No Such Thing as a Free Breakfast
description: In the defining scene of the pilot episode of The Deuce, a Times Square prostitute named Candy, played by Maggie Gyllenhaal, agrees to deflower a nervous student named Stewart for the going rate of 30 and 10  $30 for the service, $10 for the room. Once they get up to the room and Candy gets down to business, however, Stewarts excitement and inexperience betrays him, much as it has many overeager young men in his position.

title: Hillary Clinton on Her Political Future: I Am Done With Being a Candidate
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Clinton, who grapples with her second failed presidential run in a new memoir to be published Tuesday, said on Sunday that she does not plan on running again for public office.

description: Don Ohlmeyer, whose influential television career ranged from producing ABCs Monday Night Football during its 1970s heyday to guiding NBC to No. 1 in prime time two decades later on the strength of programs like Seinfeld and ER, died on Sunday in Indian Wells, Calif. He was 72.

title: A Picturesque Retreat in a Tiny Town in Puglia
description: THE ART HISTORIAN and curator Peter Benson Miller was 13 when his parents began taking him to antiques markets and junk shops near their weekend house in Litchfield County, Conn. By the time he moved for good to Italy almost 30 years later, in 2009  he is now in charge of the exhibition program and special events at the American Academy in Rome  he had amassed a huge number of objects, or, to be precise, collections of objects: 30 prints depicting Mary, Queen of Scots (I am attracted to the history of English female martyrs, he says), dozens of French ice buckets in the form of pineapples, 200 cactus-shaped vintage ceramic salt and pepper shakers from the American Southwest. He had hundreds of pieces in storage, and several hundred more jammed into the rented apartment in central Rome he shared with his partner, Giovanni Panebianco, a civil servant.

title: Gunman Kills 8 at Cookout at Suburban Dallas Home
description: HOUSTON  A gunman opened fire during a cookout for a Cowboys game at a suburban Dallas home on Sunday night, killing eight people before a police officer fatally shot him, the authorities said.

title: Dallas Cowboys, With a Jolt From Ezekiel Elliott, Overwhelm the Giants
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The rivalry between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys is long and storied. But the young men involved in the teams latest white-hot confrontations do not much care about what happened in 1960, the first time the teams met.

description: Debi Cornwalls new book on detainees at Guantnamo Bay Naval Base looks at a complicated reality that has been forgotten by most.

title: The Dogma of Dianne Feinstein
description: In September 2015, amid the Republican Partys fervid primary campaign, Ben Carson briefly outshone Donald Trump for nuttiness. The retired neurosurgeon (now the secretary of housing and urban development) declared in an interview that a Muslim should never be placed in charge of this nation. Liberals were horrified, and rightly so. Yet today liberals have their own tolerance blind spot, and Christians are most likely to get caught in it.

title: Conspiracies, Corruption and Climate
description: After the devastation wreaked by Harvey on Houston  devastation that was right in line with meteorologists predictions  you might have expected everyone to take heed when the same experts warned about the danger posed by Hurricane Irma. But you would have been wrong.

title: Soul Survival in Trumps Hell
description: You could stay in hell for a little while if you knew that you were going to get out.

title: Remembering the Disappeared
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Of the 2,753 victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, no physical trace has been found for 1,112 of them. Thus, for 40 percent of those who died that day, no remains have been returned to their families. In the aftermath of the carnage, some people exhibited photos, family snapshots, of those who had vanished and remained unaccounted for, despite the efforts of the authorities.

title: A Way to Get Great Teachers Into the Classroom
description: When schools reopened in New York last week, students were greeted by teachers who had spent the summer preparing for their return. Unfortunately, many of those teachers had had to devote some of their time not to lesson plans, but to a state teacher-certification process that emphasizes bureaucratic procedures more than real-world qualifications.

title: Cambodias Democracy Betrayed
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia has been in power for more than 30 years. On Wednesday, he vowed to stay in power. After witnessing the treasonous acts of some Cambodians in recent days, he said, I have decided to continue my job for another 10 years.

title: 9/11: Finding Answers in Ashes 16 Years Later
description: An inscription on the lobby wall greets visitors in Latin at the offices of the New York City medical examiner. It is an adage familiar to places where autopsies are performed. Reasonably translated, it says: Let conversation cease. Let laughter flee. This is the place where death rejoices to help the living.

title: The South Doesnt Own Slavery
description: The violent furor that erupted this summer over the removal of Confederate monuments in several cities was a stark reminder that Americans remain trapped in the residue of slavery and racial violence. In confronting this difficult truth, our attention is naturally drawn to the South. And rightfully so: The South was the hotbed of race-based labor and sexual exploitation before and after the Civil War, and the caldron of a white supremacist ideology that sought to draw an inviolable line between whiteness and blackness, purity and contagion, precious lives and throwaway lives. As the author of three histories on slavery and race in the South, I agree that removing Confederate iconography from cities like New Orleans, Baltimore and Charlottesville, Va., is necessary and urgent.

title: Why George Bernard Shaw Had a Crush on Stalin
description: Dublin  Shortly after midnight on Nov. 2, 1950, when the Cold War was well underway, all the illuminated signs on Broadway and Times Square were dimmed in salute to the most prominent Western admirer of Stalin. The Irish dramatist George Bernard Shaw had just died, and the tribute reflected the fame of plays such as Pygmalion, Man and Superman and Saint Joan.

title: Kris Kobach and His 5,313 Fraudulent Voters
description: The voter-fraud crusaders who run President Trumps electoral-integrity commission have found their holy grail: evidence that large-scale illegal voting swung a pivotal Senate election in 2016.

title: The Problem of Living in the Present
description: These days, many of us would rather not be living in the present, a time of persistent crisis, political uncertainty and fear. Not that the future looks better, shadowed by technological advances that threaten widespread unemployment and by the perils of catastrophic climate change. No wonder some are tempted by the comforts of a nostalgically imagined past.

title: What to Read Before Your U.S. Road Trip

Here are three books that celebrate seeing the United States at eye level.

title: Houstonians Adrift in Their City, Trying to Call Somewhere Home
description: HOUSTON  Hurricane Harveys floodwaters have left this sprawling metropolis partially ruined and eager to return to something like normalcy. But the storm has also forced many thousands of people out of their homes. As a result, the city is engaged in one giant collective improvisation. Its defining creative endeavor is where to find a place to sleep.

title: Hunting for the Promised Land, Haunted by Chuck Berry
description: Chuck Berrys 1964 classic Promised Land is all about motion. The opening guitar riff is a big and fast thing taking off, a bus leaving the station, a jet rising from the tarmac. The poor boy, our narrator, is endlessly rollin and ridin, straddling that Greyhound, smoking into New Orleans, swinging low chariot, coming down easy.

Newman, thought back to his old life, one that ended April 17, with his arrest.

His final performances, the matinees of Oct. 14 and 15, will be in George Balanchines Duo Concertant, with Sterling Hyltin.

description: WASHINGTON  Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on Monday issued a temporary order allowing the Trump administration to exclude most refugees from entering the United States while the Supreme Court considers challenges to its revised travel ban.

title: Equifaxs Maddening Unaccountability
description: Last week, Americans woke up to news of yet another mass breach of their personal data. The consumer credit reporting agency Equifax revealed that as many as 143 million Americans Social Security numbers, dates of birth, names and addresses may have been stolen from its files  just the kind of information that allows for identity theft and other cybercrimes.

title: The Contradictions of Hajj, Through the Lens of a Smartphone
description: Is it permissible to take a selfie in front of the Kaaba during hajj? With spotty internet, I was unable to Google the answer. Forced to call an audible fatwa, I decided, Yes, if indeed my intention is pure.

title: Brain-Damaged Boxer Will Receive $22 Million in Settlement With State of New York
description: The State of New York has agreed to pay $22 million to a boxer who sustained severe brain damage during a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden nearly four years ago, in a case that raised serious questions about the postfight care given to athletes who have just exchanged repeated blows to the head.

description: LOS ANGELES  This week represents the official start of Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA, some 70 museum exhibitions, from San Diego to Santa Barbara, that explore Latin American and Latino art. With galleries getting into the act, too, visitors to the shows are likely to encounter tons of new work. And two new words: Latinx and Chicanx.

Finally on Monday, after months of speculation and talks, news emerged that Ms. Jenkins would indeed be directing Wonder Woman 2.

title: Protest in Catalonia Adds to Pressure Before Independence Vote

title: Harry & Idas Opens a Luncheonette and More Food News
description: Will and Julie Horowitz, a brother-and-sister team, have opened a financial district offshoot of Harry & Idas Meat & Supply, their grocery and casual dining spot in the East Village with an Old World point of view and an emphasis on local, homemade smoked and pickled foods. This branch, called Harry & Idas Luncheonette (the name refers to the Horowitzes great-grandparents), is more spacious and serves plates priced at less than $15. We take ideas from our heritage, Mr. Horowitz said. Uptown, we did the meat thing, but, here, its more about vegetables. Youll still find Mr. Horowitzs succulent pastrami, but he is also preparing turnip-noodle kasha varnishkes, carrot tsimmes with urfa chiles and lime, and smoked apricot ras-el-hanout chicken, all available to eat in or to take out as single portions or by the pound. Pickles, sauerkraut and other items often rely on vegetable discards, like mushroom stems and the outer leaves of cabbage. Stale babka is used in burnt-sugar babka soft-serve: Harry & Idas Luncheonette, 11 Park Place (Church Street), 917-409-0028, meatandsupplyco.com.

title: Want to Make a Deal, Mr. Trump?

Probably, given this presidents pattern of poor impulse control and of reverting to base politics. But its tempting nevertheless to imagine what Mr. Trump might achieve if he could see beyond momentary, tactical wins. Hints of bipartisan consensus are popping up in Congress around enough significant issues to suggest that a determined, strategically minded president  yes, we know, but bear with us  could strike a number of important deals.

title: What Could We Lose if a NASA Climate Mission Goes Dark?
description: In late August, as Hurricane Harvey began smashing into the Texas coast, a flood of data began pouring in along with the catastrophic quantities of rainwater. It wasnt from the nonstop news coverage on CNN and elsewhere; it was from the transmissions that lay behind it, in the pulses of information coming down from space. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations geostationary and polar-orbiting satellites, crucial tools for monitoring big storms in the Gulf of Mexico, were capturing cloud formations, surface temperatures and barometric pressures, which were then fed into computer models tracking the storms strength and intensity. At the same time, NASA was using a group of satellites to keep tabs on soil moisture, flood patterns and power failures all over East Texas. In various ways, this torrent of data was being collected continuously from hundreds (or even thousands) of miles overhead, through radar instruments and spectroradiometer sensors and exquisitely calibrated imaging cameras. The machines being used arent household names  they go by acronyms like GOES-13, Modis and SMAP  but they demonstrate why the popular view of Earth as a big blue planet with only the Moon as its companion could do with some revising. We are also surrounded by a constellation of satellites spinning elliptical webs of environmental observation, day and night.

title: A Guide to Reykjavik, as Wonderfully Weird as Ever
description: As a point of divergence between the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, Iceland is home to more strange beauty than most places: snow-covered peaks, black-sand beaches, skyscraping geysers and underground caves glittering with kaleidoscopic stalactites. But the countrys drama isnt contained to its landscapes. After the 2008 banking collapse, the government imposed a steep exit tax to keep investors from moving their funds abroad. Forced to turn inward, Icelanders instead backed domestic projects like boutique hotels, locavore eateries and designer stores. In so doing, they infused Reykjavik  a compact city of just over 122,000  with a truly global feel.
