description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: Trump Pushes to Revisit Iran Nuclear Deal, and Asks Allies to Help
description: President Trump is seeking to revisit the nuclear agreement with Iran to toughen its provisions rather than scrap it right away as he has threatened, enlisting allies to pressure Tehran to return to the negotiating table, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: A Modern-Meets-Neo-Classical Apartment in Milan
description: THE QUEST FOR PERFECTION lends itself to parody: the film director demanding the 40th take; the novelist toiling over a masterpiece for a decade in a darkened room; the artist slashing the canvas in despair over an errant brush stroke.

title: Parliament Square in London Is Closer to Having First Female Statue
description: LONDON  In 1867, a statue of the statesman George Canning was moved to Parliament Square in London, across from the Palace of Westminster and Big Ben.

title: Shell Be Back ... but What Will Linda Hamiltons New Terminator Be Like?
description: For years now, the worlds Terminator fans have been comfortable in the knowledge that we would never again be excited by the prospect of seeing another film in the franchise: The last one, Terminator Genisys, was even more muddled than its title. But in an announcement this week, James Cameron, the series creator, said that another Terminator would soon be rolling off the production line. And he gave us two good reasons to hope that civilization wont be crushed by robots before its release.

title: Jake LaMotta, Raging Bull in and Out of the Ring, Dies at 95
description: Jake LaMotta, boxings Raging Bull, who brawled his way to the middleweight boxing championship in a life of unbridled fury  within the ring and outside it  that became the subject of an acclaimed film, died on Tuesday in Aventura, Fla., near Miami. He was 95.

title: Mets Painful Season Can Be Summed Up in Two Words: Steven Matz
description: Ever since the Mets selected Steven Matz out of Ward Melville High School on Long Island in the second round of the 2009 draft, his career has been defined by injuries. His latest setback, which is costing him the final month and a half of this season, helps define the current state of the Mets.

title: The True Blue Asiatic Dayflower
description: Just as the first cool hints of autumn displace summers sultry haze, Asiatic dayflowers blooms reach their peak, scattering flecks of sky blue into the corners of garden plots and local parks. As the name suggests, each bloom only lasts a day, but each plant produces many flowers, so a wet season means weeks of dayflowers. In sheltered niches, dayflowers sometimes usher in the first days of winter.

title: Moses Sumney Does Not Sing Love Songs
description: Moses Sumney has a voice that can melt hearts: a gently grainy tenor that often ascends into an immaculate, unearthly falsetto. Its no wonder that his first public gigs in Los Angeles, back in 2013, almost immediately drew fellow musicians as well as a swarm of record-label types eager to shape his music into a commercial commodity.

title: San Francisco Chefs Serve Up a Message About Climate Change
description: Karen Leibowitz and Anthony Myint opened the Perennial in San Francisco last year with a clear mission in mind: Run an environmentally friendly restaurant with a minimal carbon footprint, and inspire other restaurateurs to do the same.

title: At Mexican School Hit by Quake, Heartbreak and Dwindling Hope
description: MEXICO CITY  Gustavo Lpez recognized the boys clothes first.

title: The California Designer Behind the Unisex Label Phlemuns
description: Age 28

title: Photos from the Mexico Earthquake
description: Photos from the Mexico Earthquake

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through Oct. 9. Whitney Museum of American Art, 99 Gansevoort Street, Manhattan; 212-570-3600, whitney.org.

title: Custom Jewelry With a Hip-Hop Following
description: On Canal Street, between a huddle of tarp-covered sidewalk stalls hawking sunglasses and key chains, is a yellow sign over an awning that reads Popular Jewelry.

title: Chinese Dialects in Singapore: The Government Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: For Refugee Chefs, This Meal Is a Business Card
description: Adwa Alsubaie had never cooked outside a home kitchen until last May. Two years after she and her sister fled their home in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Ms. Alsubaie, 20, got a job in the kitchen at Emmas Torch, a brunch spot in Red Hook, Brooklyn, that doubles as a culinary school for refugees and political asylum seekers.

title: Why Mexico Is So Prone to Strong Earthquakes
description: Two strong earthquakes, 12 days apart, have shaken Mexico this month, crumpling buildings, sending panicked people into the streets, and together killing hundreds of people who were unable to escape the destruction.

title: BTS Takes a Different Approach to K-pop: Ease
description: The best song on Love Yourself: Her, the new EP from the K-pop stars BTS, isnt the main single, DNA, with its shuddering club-music drops and urgent Shawn Mendes-esque guitar intro. Nor is it Best of Me, which was written in part by Andrew Taggart, of the dim pop-EDM outfit the Chainsmokers, and fits neatly into that duos litany of songs that swell and throb yet still feel like dirges.

title: Lillian Ross, Acclaimed Reporter for The New Yorker, Dies at 99
description: Lillian Ross, who became known as the consummate fly-on-the-wall reporter in more than six decades at The New Yorker, whether writing about Ernest Hemingway, Hollywood or a busload of Indiana high school seniors on a class trip to New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 99.

title: The Awful Beauty of the White War
description: The caption that appeared 100 years ago in The New York Times Mid-Week Pictorial referred to a picturesque scene in the Dolomites, where Italian soldiers were defending the frontier against Austrian and German invasion.

title: Gucci: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Europe Renews Offensive on Silicon Valley With Tax Reforms
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions offensive against Silicon Valley looks as though it is likely to resume, as officials in Brussels consider a raft of proposals aimed at increasing the amount of tax paid by digital titans like Facebook and Amazon.

title: Bigger Libraries for New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Follow Kenyas Example on Plastic Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: Confident Fed Sets Stage for December Rate Increase
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly a decade after the Federal Reserve embarked on an unprecedented effort to shore up the collapsing American economy, the central bank said on Wednesday that it would begin withdrawing some of the trillions of dollars it invested in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

title: G.O.P.s $1.5 Trillion Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: The Far Away Brothers Breathes Vivid Life Into Immigration Issues
description: If, as a public official, your best solution to a complicated problem is to build a wall, the odds are pretty good youll eventually smack into one. A wall was the thousand-mile backdrop to Donald J. Trumps 2016 presidential campaign. But as weve seen over the past few weeks, with the president declaring and then undeclaring his intention to end the DACA program, the realities of immigration reform are complicated. They correspond little to the anxieties of the public imagination. Realities seldom do.

title: Trumps Bellicose Speech at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: A Priceless Violin, a Cut-Rate Caper
description: In 2008, Philippe Quint, a classical violinist, left his Stradivarius in the back of a Newark airport taxi. The driver returned the instrument. Mr. Quint rewarded him and his fellow cabbies with a command performance.

title: Review: Fugues, Rags and Dylan by Twyla Tharp. Oh, She Dances Too.
description: Twyla Tharp is a brand name twice over. Shes the maker of both a large, epoch-making body of choreography and a legendarily sensuous dance style.

title: T Fashion Editors Guide to Milan
description: Classic Milanese Meals

title: Prosecutors Want Anthony Weiner to Serve About 2 Years in Prison
description: Anthony D. Weiner, the disgraced former Democratic congressman, has asked not to serve any prison time for his conviction in a sexting case. But his request for probation was simply inadequate, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday, adding that his crime deserves time in prison.

title: On a California Ranch, Perfect Conditions for Pro Surfing
description: The worlds top professional surfers got a glimpse of their competitive future on Tuesday: an assembly line of perfect waves, each one identical to the one before it, and all breaking at perfectly timed intervals.

title: Forget Fan Fiction. In Nerdlesque, the Garters Come Off.
description: On stage at the Slipper Room this month, Lilly Hayes, the performer known as Miranda Raven, kicked off her black moon boots before zipping out of her astronaut costume to reveal a pair of jeans, white button-down shirt and denim jacket  the signature look of River Song, a character from Doctor Who.

title: Months After Second Avenue Subway Opening, Safety Testing Is Not Finished
description: In a rush to finish New York Citys long-awaited Second Avenue subway by a New Years Day deadline imposed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority failed to complete final safety testing before opening the line to the public, according to oversight reports submitted to the federal government.

title: Republicans Defend Health Bill Against Another Adversary: Jimmy Kimmel
description: WASHINGTON  Hours after Jimmy Kimmel unleashed a monologue attacking the latest bill that would undo much of the Affordable Care Act, two of the bills authors spent Wednesday morning defending the legislation against the late-night host, who in recent months has become an unlikely  and increasingly impassioned  critic.

title: Mueller Seeks White House Documents Related to Trumps Actions as President
description: WASHINGTON  Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, has asked the White House for documents about some of President Trumps most scrutinized actions since taking office, including the firing of his national security adviser and F.B.I. director, according to White House officials.

title: In Central Park, Teaching Dogs to Sit (in Yiddish)
description: The humans gathered for coffee and chocolate rugelach at the check-in table near the 67th Street and Fifth Avenue entrance of Central Park. The dogs sampled homemade apple cookies, or kichel, and sipped water. Owners were encouraged to take training treats to keep in their pockets.

title: How to Conquer Fashions New Frontier
description: Are you feeling nostalgic for a certain kind of America, one that was simpler, wilder and full of possibility? Fashion sure is. Themes and motifs pillaged from the Wild West  or our fantasy of it  played out all over the fall 2017 runways, most notably at Raf Simonss debut collection for Calvin Klein, which featured bygone staples in unexpected color combinations.

title: Hating Mother!: Readers Speak Out
description: It may not have attracted mass audiences, but Mother!, Darren Aronofskys allegorical thriller, did succeed in getting a lot of people talking  even if they hadnt seen the movie. Mother!, which stars Jennifer Lawrence and Javier Bardem, is meant to be a parable about climate change and environmental destruction, as Mr. Aronofsky and Ms. Lawrence revealed in a recent New York Times article. Critics were divided  A.O. Scott called it a hoot  but on nytimes.com and on our Facebook page, most moviegoers werent persuaded. Here is a selection of their comments, edited for length and clarity.

title: Where to Donate to Mexico Earthquake Victims
description: The powerful earthquake that struck Mexico on Tuesday has killed more than 200 people, and more deaths are expected. Buildings collapsed across Mexico City, including a school where at least 30 students were believed to have been killed. Rescuers on Wednesday scrambled to dig out people trapped beneath rubble.

title: The 15 Best Photos of London Fashion Week
description: Highlights from Versus, J.W. Anderson and more shows at London Fashion Week.

title: Our Favorite Photos of London Fashion Week
description: London Fashion Week came to a close with the Tommy Hilfiger show on Tuesday evening. To cover the week, Ts photographers fanned out across the city to capture Molly Goddardss party-within-a-show, Simone Rochas Edwardian-inspired show  and much more.

title: Graham-Cassidy Has One Great Idea
description: The latest Republican stab at overhauling the Affordable Care Act manages to be both more timid and more sweeping than previous efforts to replace Obamacare. Known as Graham-Cassidy, it was written by a quartet of Republican senators led by Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Bill Cassidy of Louisiana.

title: Emboldened China Wields Its Laws to Silence Critics From Abroad
description: BEIJING  On the morning he disappeared, the activist Lee Ming-cheh crossed from Macau into mainland China to meet with democracy advocates.

title: Yes, We Need to Do Better: World Leaders Talk Democracy
description: At the Athens Democracy Forum, a conference convened by The New York Times in Athens, from Sept. 13 to 17, global leaders talked about the state of democracy and its challenges around the world. The following are edited excerpts from several of the participants, who discussed the relevancy of international organizations like the United Nations how to better engage young people in the democratic process, policy strategies can help bring democracy to the developing world and what are some new models to consider.

title: Voter Fraud? A Trump Nominee Looks as if He Cast an Illegal Ballot
description: WASHINGTON  As President Trumps voter integrity commission looks under rocks for possible voter malfeasance, its members might want to examine a presidential nominee awaiting confirmation by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Street Style: London
description: The fashion crowds move to Britain for London Fashion Week, bringing their best street style looks along for the trip.

title: If You Shame Them, Will They Pay?
description: Zoila Darton and Angela Carrasco felt sad about the state of womens rights in the United States, and they decided to channel some of their frustration into action.

title: 8 Pedestrian-Friendly U.S. Cities to Explore
description: Cities like Boston, Chicago, New York and San Francisco, with their extensive public transportation systems, have long been go-to destinations for carless travelers. But a few unexpected locales have joined the list, thanks to new and expanding transit options. In honor of Car Free Day  Friday, Sept. 22  take stock of these old (and new) pedestrian-friendly American destinations.

title: Battered, Not Broken: Pictures of Mexico After the Quake
description: The earthquake that devastated Mexico on Tuesday knocked over dozens of buildings in the capital alone, killed children at a school and sent waves of people running into the streets for safety  for the second time in just two weeks.

title: Wild Bison Killed After Wandering Across Border Into Germany
description: Last week, a rare wild bison was spotted wandering alone near the town of Lebus in eastern Germany. A local official, alarmed that the animal could be dangerous, ordered hunters to shoot it and one of them did, using a rifle to kill an animal that had not freely roamed Germany for several hundred years, conservationists say.

title: Chuck and Nancy, Washingtons New Power Couple, Set Sights on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, introduced Chuck Schumer to members of her caucus this month, she warmed up the room with a well-worn joke about her Senate counterpart: You know they say the most dangerous place in Washington is between Chuck and a camera.

title: Hurricane Maria, Mexico City, Iran: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Fausto Puglisi: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Review: In Kingsman: The Golden Circle, the Natty Spies Are Back
description: Kill Elton John! is a line youre unlikely to hear in the average spy caper, but Kingsman: The Golden Circle aims far above average. Like its 2015 predecessor, this latest visit with the British agents-cum-Savile Row tailors swings for the fences without caring whose head  or torso, or dignity  is shredded en route. Even if it belongs to Sir Elton.

title: Richard Robinson of Scholastic Honored for Lifetime of Work in Childrens Publishing
description: Richard Robinson, the man responsible for bringing Harry Potter to American readers, among many other career highlights in childrens publishing, has been named the winner of the 2017 Literarian Award for Outstanding Service to the American Literary Community, the National Book Foundation announced Wednesday.

title: Modern Love Podcast: Kerry Bish Reads One Bouquet of Fleeting Beauty, Please
description: On this weeks episode, the actress Kerry Bish (Halt and Catch Fire, Narcos) reads the 2015 essay One Bouquet of Fleeting Beauty, Please, about why we send flowers.

title: New Trailer: A Jumanji for the Video Game Age
description: The new trailer for Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle, which arrived Wednesday, suggests its less of a sequel to the Robin Williams 1995 family favorite than it is to Central Intelligence, the 2016 comedy with Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart. Theyre part of the ensemble in the new film, but their easy slapstick chemistry ultimately takes center stage in the trailer, pushing aside even their co-star, the veteran scenery chewer Jack Black.

title: Avoiding Cameras While Training the Lens on Food
description: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Pete Wells, The Timess restaurant critic, discussed the tech he is using.

title: De Blasios Gap on Climate Policy? Its Under His Front Door
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to be seen as a leader in fighting global warming, and he says that everyone needs to do their part. But when it comes to two buildings he owns in Brooklyn, its not clear that he is following his own advice.

title: Line Drive Strikes Young Girl in the Face at Yankee Stadium
description: The Yankees easily completed a three-game sweep of the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday and bolstered their bid for a postseason berth, but all of that was overshadowed by an unsettling incident in the fifth inning, when a line drive off the bat of Todd Frazier appeared to hit the face of a young girl who was seated directly behind the third-base dugout.

title: For Hispanic Heritage Month, 3 Books on Latinos in the U.S.
description: In recognition of National Hispanic Heritage Month, which runs from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15 and coincides with the Independence Days of a number of Latin American countries including Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico, here are three books on Latinos history, culture and experiences in the United States.

title: New Trailer: Tomb Raider Aims to Mint a New Action Star
description: Stop us if youve heard this one before: A few years after winning an Academy Award for best supporting actress, a rising star makes the leap to above-the-title action heroine as Lara Croft from the video game Tomb Raider. In 2001, it was Angelina Jolie (Girl, Interrupted), and now its Alicia Vikander (The Danish Girl).

title: Long Plaid Skirts to Wear This Fall
description: British designers have a history of toying with the enduring plaid skirt  the tartan kilt is, after all, a sartorial totem of Scottishness. The English designer Vivienne Westwood gave the style a punk treatment, ruching it in rebellious ways in the 80s (and continues to do so today) and the late Alexander McQueen played with the idea from the beginning of his career, with his controversial Highland Rape collection in the 90s, cutting a Royal Stuart red wool tartan in a dangerously low-cut pencil skirt. For her spring 2018 collection, shown in London last weekend, Margaret Howell presented a characteristically minimal A-line skirt in a black and white cotton silk check that reminded me of starched schoolgirl uniforms, golden September days in New England and the tea-length hemlines of the late 1930s and 1940s that feel spot-on today. Howells design will be available with the first buds of spring, but for a tartan fix now, here are a few appealing autumnal options.

title: Hack Will Lead to Little, if Any, Punishment for Equifax
description: Its a bad week when one senator says that somebody needs to go to jail for selling shares in your company before it disclosed a massive data breach, and another asserts that the episode was one of the most egregious examples of corporate malfeasances since Enron.

title: A Paintbrush in One Hand, and a Drink in the Other
description: BENTONVILLE, Ark.  On a rainy Friday evening in August, customers trickled into an art studio in a strip mall on a busy main road here. The crowd, mostly women, chatted and swarmed a bar for wine and beer before taking stools at paper-covered tables and turning to the task at hand: painting.

title: Facebook, After Fail Over Ads Targeting Racists, Makes Changes
description: Responding to evidence that its tools had allowed ads to be directed at users who used racist comments or hate speech in their profiles, Facebook said Wednesday that it would change how ads can be targeted.

title: Christopher Bailey Captures His Week  in Polaroids
description: 5:30 p.m., Wednesday Sept. 13: Trying an earring on a male model in the design studio at Horseferry House.

title: How Can U.S. States Fight Climate Change if Trump Quits the Paris Accord?
description: WASHINGTON  In the months since President Trump declared that the United States would withdraw from the Paris climate deal, 14 state governors have vowed to continue upholding the agreement and press ahead with policies to fight global warming.

title: Sea Turtles Appear to Be Bouncing Back Around the World
description: On this planet, so many plants and animals are disappearing that scientists worry were experiencing a sixth mass extinction. Many of these organisms are taking hits from a variety of angles  habitat loss, climate change and more  that its hard to get a grasp on how to stop their declines. Conservation success stories are rare.

title: Dr. Edmond Eger II, 86, Dies; Found Way to Make Anesthesia Safer
description: Dr. Edmond I. Eger II, a leader in the development of a now universally used technique to determine the proper dose of anesthetic gas administered in operating rooms  an advance that has saved an untold number of lives  died on Aug. 26 at his home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 86.

title: Ignore TV Ratings: Golf Is Healthier Than It Appears
description: ATLANTA  Jim Sanford was hitting microchipped golf balls off a mat between swigs of beer and bites of sushi. He was wearing flip flops. It was a recent 100-degree Sunday night in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Sanford and his date, Karen Boldt, were playing Topgolf, a cross between Skee-Ball and archery, with the ambience of an outdoor bowling alley, in which participants take aim at 11 color-coded targets, accruing points for accuracy and distance.

title: LeBron Jamess Future May Depend on Nets Success or Failure
description: The opportunity was presented in a variety of ways, the question posed in various forms. But on the subject of the Nets, and their progress as a team this coming season, Kenny Atkinson wouldnt bite and neither would Sean Marks.

title: Dogs of Wall Street
description: Dear Diary:

title: Mexico City, Hurricane Maria, Iran: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Rochester Launches New Inquiry Into Harassment Accusations
description: The University of Rochester, assailed by outrage from students and alumni over accusations that it covered up a professors sexual harassment, has placed the professor on leave and hired one of the countrys most prominent lawyers to lead a renewed investigation into the allegations.

title: Review: The Lego Ninjago Movie Sticks to the Instruction Manual
description: When are the Wegos coming on? the young boy sitting next to me asked his father. His impatience was reasonable enough. Here we were, five minutes into The Lego Ninjago Movie, gazing at a live-action prologue with Jackie Chan, a kid and a cat in a store full of exotic knickknacks.

title: Former Apple Engineers Working on New Eyes for Driverless Cars
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Soroush Salehian raised both arms and spun in circles as if celebrating a touchdown.

title: At Menendez Trial, Legal Wrestling Over Definition of Constituent
description: NEWARK  There are 325 million people living in the United States. About 56 million of those people claim Hispanic heritage.

title: A Start-Up Slump Is a Drag on the Economy. Big Business May Be to Blame.
description: Unemployment has fallen, and the stock market has soared. So why has the economic expansion since the recession been so tame, with sluggish productivity and, at least until recently, anemic wage growth?

title: Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Last month, Facebook and Google came out forcefully against a bill that would hold companies accountable for hosting sex trafficking on their websites. They said that while they worked hard to combat sex trafficking, changing the law jeopardizes bedrock principles of a free and open internet that have been crucial to innovation for decades.

title: Quotation of the Day: Pills Are Everywhere: Opioid Crisis and Its Youngest Victims
description: There are no pill parties happening in preschools. These kids arent making a choice because they are trying to get high on a substance.

title: These Were Our Children: School Collapses in Mexico Earthquake
description: At least 30 children were killed when the Enrique Rebsamen school collapsed in Tuesdays earthquake.

title: Someone Made a Fake Equifax Site. Then Equifax Linked to It.
description: People create fake versions of big companies websites all the time, usually for phishing purposes. But the companies do not usually link to them by mistake.

title: Insurers Come Out Swinging Against New Republican Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The health insurance industry, after cautiously watching Republican health care efforts for months, came out forcefully on Wednesday against the Senates latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, suggesting that its state-by-state block grants could create health care chaos in the short term and a Balkanized, uncertain insurance market.

title: At James Blake Trial, Judge Invokes Law Shielding Police Records
description: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has steadily expanded the citys interpretation of a state law that bars public disclosure of the personnel records of police officers, firefighters and corrections officers.

title: Florida Nursing Home Listed Dead Resident as Resting in Bed, State Says
description: A state agency has found that the Florida nursing home where eight residents  died after it lost air-conditioning following Hurricane Irma presents a danger to every person on its premises and must close after staff at the facility failed to call 911 for its overheated patients, even as their temperatures began spiking as high as 109.9 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Pakistans Leader Says Military Has Routed Taliban From Afghan Border
description: Pakistans new leader, stung by President Trumps threat to crack down on his country for harboring terrorists, insisted on Wednesday that Pakistani military forces had uprooted all the sanctuaries used by Islamic extremists along its rugged frontier with Afghanistan.

title: Manafort Working on Kurdish Referendum Opposed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Paul J. Manafort, the former campaign chairman for President Trump who is at the center of investigations into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, is working for allies of the leader of Iraqs Kurdish region to help administer and promote a referendum on Kurdish independence from Iraq.

title: Mattis Shows How to Split With Trump Without Provoking Him
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly all of President Trumps top national security officials have been the target of his ire, whether it was privately dressing down his attorney general, publicly disagreeing with his top diplomat or musing about exiling his national security adviser to Afghanistan.

title: Critics Fear Trumps Attacks on Iran Could Backfire
description: UNITED NATIONS  President Trumps bombastic attacks on Iran over the nuclear deal may have created an unanticipated outcome: sympathy for the Iranian government.

title: Maria Strikes, and Puerto Rico Goes Dark
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Read the latest with Thursdays live updates on Hurricane Maria.

title: Spokeswoman Cites Demanding Schedule for Health Secretarys Use of Private Jets
description: WASHINGTON  Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, spent tens of thousands of taxpayer dollars to fly on private jets to attend routine public events instead of taking cheaper commercial airliners because he has an incredibly demanding schedule, his spokeswoman said Wednesday.

title: Preet Bharara, Ousted Federal Prosecutor, Will Join CNN
description: Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney in Manhattan, has been far from silent since being ousted from his job in March. He is writing a book, regularly muses on politics and legal matters to his 438,000 followers on Twitter, and just started a podcast. (First episode: That Time President Trump Fired Me.)

title: The New York Times in Australia? Yes. Heres Why.
description: This FAQ was updated on November 23, 2018.

title: Bernie Casey, Who Glided From Football to Hollywood, Dies at 78
description: Bernie Casey, an accomplished National Football League receiver who successfully painted and acted in dozens of films, including Revenge of the Nerds, Brians Song and Im Gonna Git You Sucka, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

title: Operatic Villains, Often
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Matt Ginsberg is back. This is his 46th Times puzzle, but only the first this year. Its a classic Thursday: tricky and fun. (I pause here to recognize those solvers who dont find tricky to be fun. Im afraid Thursday is not always their day.)

title: Deaf Man Is Fatally Shot by Oklahoma City Police, Despite Pleas
description: An Oklahoma City police officer fatally shot a man on Tuesday night despite pleas from neighbors that the man was deaf and could not hear the commands to drop a metal pipe he was holding, the authorities said.

title: S.E.C. Says It Was a Victim of Computer Hacking Last Year
description: HONG KONG  The top securities regulator in the United States said Wednesday night that its computer system had been hacked last year, giving the attackers private information that could have been exploited for trading.

title: Google Is Buying HTCs Smartphone Expertise for $1.1 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google announced late Wednesday night that it is spending $1.1 billion to hire a team of engineers from the smartphone business of the struggling Taiwanese manufacturer HTC in a bid to bring more hardware expertise to its own mobile technology operations.

title: Corrections: September 21, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Merkel Says Germans Never Had It Better. But Many Feel Left Behind.
description: BREMERHAVEN, Germany  In her campaign speeches, Chancellor Angela Merkel loves to tell potential voters in next weeks election that they are living in the best Germany ever. Last year she boasted to Parliament that Germans have never had it better.

title: For Laver Cup, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal Are on the Same Side
description: PRAGUE  In the back seat of a new van in an old city, a stubble-faced Rafael Nadal was laughing hard on my right and a stubble-faced Roger Federer was laughing harder on my left.

title: How to Hack Your Brain (for $5,000)
description: EDEN, Utah  One morning last month a group of roughly 60 people, including doctors, C.E.O.s and internet entrepreneurs, gathered under a big white dome to hear the mission statement of their host, a 45-year-old man named Jamie Wheal.

title: In Landlocked Milan, Try the Fish
description: Milan has no sea. It has no river or lake, just a few ebbing canals. But this landlocked city is famous for some of the best seafood in the long, double-coasted peninsula of Italy, thanks mostly to the concrete warehouse of the Mercato Ittico that my guide, Sandra Ciciriello, had sneaked me inside.

title: Mexico, Iran, Catalonia: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Voyages Issue: How Do Families Around the World Spend Their Vacations?
description: Photo essays from around the world by Joakim Eskildsen, Moises Saman, Sim Chi Yin, Mark Neville, Mamadi Doumbouya, Massimo Vitali, Newsha Tavakolian, Justine Kurland and Christopher Anderson.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: The Return of Doc Martin and Gotham
description: Portwenns stiff doctor tries to salvage his marriage for the sake of his baby. And the crime-ridden city of Gotham finally gets its hero in Season 4.

title: Word + Quiz: incendiary
Tackle Football
description: Do you play tackle football?

title: How to Find a Qualified Dog Trainer
description: When it comes to finding a trainer for Fido, beware of dog ... trainer.

title: Trump Likened to a Dog Barking by North Koreas Top Envoy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas foreign minister likened President Trump to a dog barking, ridiculing the American leader for threatening to totally destroy his country if it persists in its nuclear and missile threats.

title: Meet the Man Who Dresses Melania Trump
description: Herv Pierre designs for a very specific customer: First Lady Melania Trump. We take you inside his New York City studio.

title: Herv Pierre Is Designing Melania Trumps Legacy
description: In the latest installment of our video series that goes inside the private working worlds of designers, the consultant Herv Pierre, the former creative director of Carolina Herrera who as the designer of Melania Trumps inaugural gown shot to fame in January, reveals how he ended up as the first ladys stylist, where he shops and whether he will start his own label. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: Global Voices and Emerging Photographers at Photoville
description: Photoville, the temporary photo festival underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring emergicubes, 4x4 foot cubes displaying the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers.

title: Moscows Monument to Murder
description: Like many a statue in the United States that we have struggled over of late, the towering monument to Mikhail Kalashnikov, unveiled in a highly visible spot in Moscow on Tuesday, seems to have been put up for mostly the wrong reasons. The statue was promoted by the Russian culture minister, Vladimir Medinsky, a nationalist who spends much of his time glorifying Russian military history and who described the familiar assault weapon General Kalashnikov invented, which is widely known by his name, as a true cultural brand of Russia.

title: The Smart Way to Get Tough With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  As the two negotiators who initiated the secret talks that led to the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement, we are intimately familiar with the deals strengths, its inevitable imperfections and the wider challenge posed by Iran.

title: Meet the Worlds Leaders, in Hypocrisy
description: Leaders from around the world have descended on New York for United Nations meetings, fancy parties, ringing speeches about helping the poor  and a big dose of hypocrisy.

title: Are We Down to President Pence?
description: Donald Trumps visit to the United Nations has resurrected the question of whether wed be better off with Mike Pence.

title: Tax Cuts for the Rich by Another Name
description: Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee violated their supposedly sacrosanct principles of fiscal hawkishness this week, by saying that it would be just fine with them to add $1.5 trillion to the deficit over 10 years in order to cut taxes. They justify this hypocrisy by asserting what has been disproved time and again  that tax cuts spur the economy and compensate for any lost revenue.

title: Lets Stop Government Giveaways to Corporations
description: Amazon recently sent state and city officials across the country scrambling to respond to its announcement that it was seeking enticements to build a second headquarters, promising 50,000 new jobs and $5 billion in investment to the winning location. Governments are mobilizing to devise lucrative incentive packages. I know how this works, because I spent eight years supporting these types of incentives as the governor of Delaware.

title: Get Rid of Equifax
description: Because of lax security at Equifax, one of the three major credit reporting companies, the private financial and personal details of as many as 143 million Americans have been exposed to hackers. We still dont know what the full ramifications will be; the people who took this information  which includes birth dates, Social Security numbers and addresses  could hold on to it for as long as they want and deploy it in years to come.

title: Global Voices and Emerging Photographers at Photoville
description: Photoville, the temporary community of duplexes made by four-ton steel shipping containers underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers from Africa, Asia, Latin America and the United States, displayed on four-foot wooden cubes. The photographers were chosen from participants in this years New York Portfolio Review  a free event sponsored by The New York Times Lens blog and The City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Hurricane Maria Updates: In Puerto Rico, the Storm Destroyed Us
description: Read the latest on Hurricane Maria with Fridays live updates.

title: Teaching Activities for: Mexico Earthquake Kills Hundreds, Trapping Many Under Rubble
description: Before reading the article:

title: What Is Your Reaction to President Trumps United Nations General Assembly Speech?
description: Watch the video above, which shows excerpts from President Trumps first speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

title: 36 Hours in Madrid
description: There has never been a better time to visit the Spanish capital, where the political and economic turmoil of the past decade has helped spur creativity and enterprise.

title: Celeste Ng: By the Book
description: The author of, most recently, Little Fires Everywhere, often returns to The Count of Monte Cristo: Right now, I see it as an exploration of the complexities of good and evil and how easily one shifts into the other.

title: 36 Hours in Madrid
description: Spend 36 Hours in Madrid, Spains vibrant capital.

title: Streampunks Serves Up YouTubes Greatest Hits
description: STREAMPUNKS YouTube and the Rebels Remaking Media By Robert Kyncl with Maany Peyvan 272 pp. Harper Business. $29.99

title: Monsantos Weed Killer, Dicamba, Divides Farmers
description: Farmers planted a new kind of seed on 25 million acres of soybean and cotton fields this year. Developed by Monsanto, the seeds, genetically modified to be resistant to a weed killer called dicamba, are one of the biggest product releases in the companys history.

title: Michael Phelps: A Golden Shoulder to Lean On
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Nearly a week into their most recent therapeutic reunion, Michael Phelps and Grant Hackett, two giants of Olympic swimming, sat down to breakfast at a packed restaurant and wondered how they would explain themselves to their children someday.

title: When the Governments of the World Agreed to Banish War
description: THE INTERNATIONALISTS How a Radical Plan to Outlaw War Remade the World By Oona A. Hathaway and Scott J. Shapiro Illustrated. 581 pp. Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: Battle Over Confederate Monuments Moves to the Cemeteries
description: MADISON, Wis.  One by one, Confederate monuments are coming down from their perches in front of courthouses, in public squares, along city boulevards.

title: On Star Trek: Discovery, a Franchise Boldly Goes Into the Serial TV Era
description: Space, in the Star Trek universe, may be an alluring and infinite frontier, but time is a much rarer and more vexing commodity.

title: How to Use Twitter and Facebook for Emergency Travel Information
description: You dont have to like Twitter or Facebook, or even post to them, but when an emergency strikes, the networking sites can be essential travel tools.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Doubles Down on Criticism of Health Care Bill
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: The G.O.P. Bill Forces States to Build Health Systems From Scratch. Thats Hard.
description: In 2003, health care policy makers in Massachusetts agreed that the state should build a system to expand coverage to its uninsured residents.

title: Hurricane Maria, North Korea, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: One Last Visit to See My Patient
description: The rain was coming down in torrents and my shoes were not up to the job. Nevertheless, I pressed forward along the soggy blocks. My 91-year-old patient and I had been together for some 20 years  honestly Id lost count  so this was the least I could do.

title: How Technology Changes Teen Romance
description: The topic of teenage romance and sex has always been charged, but todays pervasive digital technology has succeeded in turning up the wattage. Some parents have an easy and open channel with their adolescent around all things amorous while others find the subject painfully awkward and try to avoid it altogether. Regardless of where you and your teenager sit on this spectrum, the digital world puts a new spin on some of the timeless challenges of coming of age. When youre ready to talk, here are some points to consider.

title: Review: The Documentary Bobbi Jene Finds a Dancer in Flux
description: Enigmatic to an extreme, the documentary Bobbi Jene may interest viewers who are well versed in contemporary dance. All others are on their own.

title: No Child Trapped in Rubble of Mexican Quake-Hit School, Officials Say
description: After a day in which Mexico was captivated by frantic rescue operations to reach a girl believed to be trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed elementary school, officials said Thursday that they believed there was no girl there.

title: Review: A Sweet Immigrant Story in The Tiger Hunter
description: A gentle, warmhearted immigrant comedy thats rarely more than mildly amusing, The Tiger Hunter follows Sami (Danny Pudi), an aspiring engineer, from his rural Indian village to a job opportunity in Chicago.

title: Review: Lady Gaga Unplugged, Sort Of, in Gaga: Five Foot Two
description: Even when the pop music provocateur known as Lady Gaga seemed to be changing personae by the hour, one eyebrow-raising costume or public gesture after another, those paying proper attention could discern a disciplined, focused performer/musician behind the choreographed madness. While the movie climaxes with preparations for Gagas strangely spectacular 2017 Super Bowl halftime show, it mostly chronicles the artist at work in 2016 on a project that would ostensibly present her unplugged, so to speak.

title: New York Today: Theater in Odd Places
description: Good morning on this balmy Thursday, and Shanah Tovah.

title: Review: Unrest, a Personal Account of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
description: Nearly 30 years after chronic fatigue syndrome was given its unfortunate name, its still not understood or even completely accepted by the medical world: No definitive cause has been identified, nor any consensus treatment. And while it affects an estimated 1 million Americans and 17 million globally, those with the condition are often dismissed as suffering from psychosomatic disorders.

title: Listen to The Daily: One More Bid to Repeal Obamacare
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: S.&P. Downgrades Chinas Debt, Citing a Surge in Lending
description: SHANGHAI  China and the world received a fresh warning on Thursday that the countrys dramatic debt binge of recent years threatens the stability of one of the global economys most important growth engines.

title: Review: Victoria and Abdul, a Royal Friendship in a Nest of Vipers
description: This is the second movie in 20 years in which Judi Dench plays Queen Victoria. And this is the second movie in 20 years in which Queen Victoria, played by Judi Dench, has a life-enhancing relationship with a man not of her station. This movie, Victoria and Abdul, directed by Stephen Frears from a script by Lee Hall, goes 1997s Mrs. Brown one better in the Relevant to Contemporary Concerns department by depicting a friendship between the second-longest-reigning monarch of England and an Indian Muslim.

title: Max Mara: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: Review: The Kings Choice Depicts Norways Entry Into World War II
description: A saga of Norways entry into World War II that probably plays more stirringly in the nation where it is set, The Kings Choice dramatizes a celebrated moment in the countrys constitutional monarchy, when King Haakon VII (Jesper Christensen) refused to surrender to the Nazis invasion.

title: Why Trumps Softening on Immigration Is Unlikely to Splinter His Base
description: In a matter of weeks, President Trump has twice struck deals with Democrats in Congress that have left many of his supporters flummoxed.

title: Review: Loving Vincent Paints van Gogh in His Own Images
description: Loving Vincent addresses its subject, the Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh, with two what-ifs  one marvelous and fantastical, the other empirical and pedestrian. What if his paintings, with their wild colors and vibrant brush strokes, had been able to move? And what if the bullet that killed him had been fired by someone else?

title: Morning Agenda: Google Gets Serious About Producing Better Phones
description: Google once owned a phone maker. It didnt work out. Now its trying a different approach.

title: Remember When They Wanted to Build a Parking Lot Over the Hudson?
description: The first item in Never Built New York, a thought-provoking tour of models, drawings, and newspaper headlines at the Queens Museum, is a cocktail napkin from the Plaza Hotel. On it, Frank Lloyd Wright sketched an idea for remaking Ellis Island.

title: Review: Hong Kong Trilogy, Captures the Voices of the People
description: Directed by the cinematographer Christopher Doyle, Hong Kong Trilogy: Preschooled, Preoccupied, Preposterous is drawn from the real voices of contemporary Hong Kong residents, a title card says. More of a poem or a city symphony than a documentary, it drifts freely, sometimes frustratingly between captured and fictionalized moments.

title: Review: Jake Gyllenhaal in Stronger Loses His Legs in the Boston Bombing
description: Stronger, the new movie directed by David Gordon Green, harks back to his work in the first decade of this century. His All the Real Girls (2003) and Snow Angels (2007) brought acute, cleareyed, compassionate consideration to trauma and tragedy as they affect intimate relationships. Unlike those pictures, though, Stronger carries a separate weight. Its also about an actual galvanic event in recent American history.

title: California Today: Mexico Has a Quake Warning System. Where is Californias?
description: Good morning.

title: A Marine Le Pen Aide Leaves Far-Right Party
description: PARIS  A top aide to the French far-right leader Marine Le Pen announced on Thursday that he was leaving her National Front party, the latest sign of turmoil in the organization as it struggles to recover from her defeat in the presidential election this year.

title: A Head-Spinning, Hope-Inspiring Showcase of Art
description: LOS ANGELES  I guess theres a God. During one of the meanest passages in American national politics within living memory, were getting a huge, historically corrective, morale-raising cultural event, one that lasts four months and hits on many of the major social topics of the day: racism, sexism, aggressive nationalism. True, the hugeness of the thing is a problem, and the contents are uneven. But its a gift, worth a trip to puzzle over and savor.

title: On the Market in New York and New Jersey
description: This weeks properties include a penthouse in Hoboken, N.J., and a bayfront in Merrick, N.Y.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York and New Jersey:

title: Text to Text | Wonder and Stories About Disability Dont Have to Be Sad
description: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks homes are on the Upper West Side, in the West Village, and in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Patient Voices: Alzheimers Disease
description: A slow decline in memory, an inability to complete simple tasks, the concern about long-term care - five men and women speak about living with and caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease.

title: Fendi: Spring 2018
description: The label shows its spring looks.

title: The Most Pet-Friendly Cities in the United States
description: We love our pets, and we have a lot of them: According to a recent survey conducted by the American Pet Products Association, there are about 90 million dogs and 94 million cats kept as pets in the United States. If you take into account canaries, rabbits, fish and other animals, the total number of pets in the country is a staggering 393 million  in 68 percent of American households. Pets are everywhere, but the quality and cost of living with them varies considerably depending on where you live.

title: Fantasy Football: The Best Players to Start in Week 3
description: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

title: On Trump at the United Nations
description: As president of the United States, I will always put America first, just like you, as the leaders of your countries, will always and should always put your countries first, President Trump said.

title: Meet Wetex Kang, the First Asian on New Zealands Maori Party Ticket
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Wetex Kang, a Malay-Chinese immigrant beekeeper, may be the first Asian candidate to represent the Maori Party of New Zealand, but at times he sounds more like a certain American president.

title: Retiring the Google Drive Desktop App
description: Q. Is it true that Google Drive is being discontinued?

title: In Country Music, Nice Guys Finish First (for Now)
description: If, in the fall of 2015, you pressed play on Tangled Up, the second album from the young country singer Thomas Rhett, you would have thought he fit right in.

title: Review: The Scandalous Friendship That Shaped Adam Smith
description: Although Adam Smith had no children, he has been identified as either the father of economics or, more expansively, of modern capitalism. And to be sure, the continuing relevance of his masterwork, The Wealth of Nations, published at the moment our nation came to be in 1776, is undeniable.

title: 8 of the Seasons Best Crystal Earrings
description: Chandelier styles  flashy, glamorous and unapologetically decadent  with a punk-rock edge.

title: Seven Brian De Palma Movies Worth Streaming
description: The director Brian De Palma was born 77 years ago this month. In honor of his birthday, I wanted to look back at some of his more memorable movies. If youd like to learn more about De Palma, who came up alongside filmmakers like Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Francis Ford Coppola, you can stream the documentary, De Palma, in which he offers up wild stories about his early days and behind-the-scenes looks at several of the movies below.

title: Some Cartoons That Missed the Cut
description: The New Yorker is highly selective of the cartoons it publishes. Here are cartoons that didnt make it.

title: The New Yorker Said No, but These Cartoons Just May Make Your Day
description: Of the 1,000 cartoons submitted to The New Yorker each week, only about 15 are published in the magazine. That is a pretty high bar, though logic might suggest there are some gems among the rejects. At least, that is David Ostows theory. He has been submitting his cartoons to the magazine since early last year, but has yet to be published in it.

title: The Center of Their Own World
Art in the Wild
description: A close look at engaging works on view in European art parks.

title: The Unique Value of Seeing Works in the Wild
description: IN 2002, Jenny Holzer was invited to create a piece at Wanas Konst, an 80-acre sculpture park tucked behind a romantic 16th-century step-gabled castle in the wilds of southern Sweden. She spent two days just wandering the grounds, where contemporary sculptures (a monumental steel chair covered in antlers, a tiny wood house in a clearing) by the likes of Marina Abramovic, Robert Wilson and Maya Lin stand amid tall beech trees and, in some cases, grazing cows. (The art foundation shares the land with a working dairy farm.) Deep in the woods, Holzer found herself thinking of fairy tales light and dark. Then she came upon a waist-high stone wall that dates to the 1700s. I started following it and knew it was the site, she says. Her contribution to what is now known as Wanas Wall was to carve a different phrase or truism from her past work into a stone block every 20 feet or so. all things are delicately interconnected, reads one.

title: NASAs Osiris-Rex Spacecraft Is Headed for a Flyby With Earth
description: A NASA spacecraft, Osiris-Rex, is speeding toward Earth after a year looping around the sun. On Friday afternoon, it will miss the planet by about 11,000 miles, zooming underneath our blue orb at 19,000 miles per hour, passing over Australia and Antarctica.

title: Citizens of Gucci-land, Unite!
description: MILAN  On a giant industrial campus in the far reaches of Milan, past the room with the giant chinoiserie swans painted on the walls and the plush velvet chairs, past the garden with its crawling ivy and purple blooms, in a cavernous space traced by a river of winding blue, a mummy lay.

title: Senator Cassidy, Please Stop Lying about Health Care
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: In New York Suburbs, Plenty of Democrats  Just Not at the Top
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.  After the presidential election in November, residents here staged an impromptu vigil. Nine days after the inauguration, more met at a local church to form a grass-roots political action group. Postcard-writing events were organized; another one, a No Democrat Left Behind postcard party, will be held later this month at The Voracious Reader, a childrens bookstore.

title: So, a President Walks Up to a Microphone...
description: By now, President Trumps sense of humor has been pretty well discussed. Either he doesnt have one, or its subtle  like a group of especially awkward 12-year-old boys yucking it up in the cafeteria.

title: Going Local: Is It Possible, as a Foreigner, to Experience a Country as Its People Do?
description: During the last few decades, a curious plague came to afflict Turkey: British luxury-travel websites or, as they were known in the tourism industry, specialist tour operators. The most notorious was Exclusive Escapes (a.k.a. Hidden Turkey). According to one advertising executives blog, its distinction was to offer off-the-beaten-track Turkish holidays for the discerning middle classes  some hotel rooms were $300 a night, but class is a moving target  and for those Britons who, the executive imagined, wanted to feel they were getting away from the crowds, who craved an authentic experience. Glorious boutique hotels sprang up along the shores of the Mediterranean and the Aegean, their multiterraced buildings cascading down Turkeys mountain slopes to the waters edge. The website promised rooms that had windows big enough to let in entire seas and real Turkish breakfasts while you watched the graceful gulet boats drift by. Its Turkey. Turkey is magical. It ought to be hard to get a vacation in Turkey wrong.

title: A Brides Countdown to Glowing Skin
description: Brides are supposed to glow on their wedding day, and that, of course, includes their skin. But who has the time to keep running to the dermatologists office for a peel, facial or fillers, especially with so many other chores to tend to?

title: Review: The Force Follows the Oakland Police From Crisis to Crisis
description: In the potent documentary The Force, theres a moment when Sean Whent, the Oakland chief of police, faces a tough critic: the public. Its 2015, and hes talking about the police response to calls. He admits the police are not providing the level of service they should but adds that theyre trying their best. When a robbery victim says their best isnt good enough, he apologizes. We need to do a better job, no doubt, and we are trying to do a better job. By the end of the movie it seems clear that he didnt apologize enough.

title: A Consumer Advocate Battles Equifax and a Storm
description: Nobody appointed me vice president of customer service for Equifax, but somebody had to do the job.

title: Columnist Biography: Nicholas D. Kristof
description: Nicholas D. Kristof, a columnist for The Times since 2001, is a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner who writes op-ed columns that appear twice a week.

title: Jake LaMotta Was More Than Just a Raging Bull
description: When a champion dies, a wave of nostalgia for his era rolls over the culture. Its like rocket summer, the wash of snow-melting heat that passes over a wintry Ohio town when spaceships lift off in Ray Bradburys Martian Chronicles. The more famous the champion, the more potent the wave.

title: Let Us Help You Find Something Great to Watch Tonight.
description: Many of this years best TV shows and movies are available to stream right now. Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site, can show you where. Tell us what mood youre in or what services you subscribe to and well help you out.

title: A Tuscan Village Bares Its Soul on Stage, Again and Again
description: MONTICCHIELLO, Italy  This walled village of just 200 residents perched in the hills south of Siena has always been a little isolated and, perhaps, a little conflicted about it.

title: War Paint to Close on Broadway in December
description: War Paint, a double-barreled musical starring Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole, will close on Broadway on Dec. 30 after 300 performances.

title: Trump Moves to Widen U.S. Sanctions on North Korea
description: President Trump ordered a widening of American sanctions on North Korea on Thursday to further choke off its trade with the outside world, in what some experts described as perhaps the most sweeping set of punitive economic measures enacted by the United States in many years.

title: KB Home to Cut C.E.O.s Bonus After His Rant Against Kathy Griffin
description: Jeffrey Mezger, chief executive of the homebuilder KB Home, will take a 25 percent cut to his year-end bonus as a result of his sexist and homophobic outburst against his neighbor, the comedian Kathy Griffin, the company said Thursday.

title: Clues to Africas Mysterious Past Found in Ancient Skeletons
description: It was only two years ago that researchers found the first ancient human genome in Africa: a skeleton in a cave in Ethiopia yielded DNA that turned out to be 4,500 years old.

title: How Three Friends Proved That Jellyfish Can Sleep
description: Worms and fish do it. Birds and bees do it. But do jellyfish fall asleep?

title: The Politics of Nondiscrimination Have Gone Too Far: Readers Debate Free Speech
description: The case of a  baker in Colorado who refused to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple has been added to the Supreme Courts docket for this fall, but thousands of New York Times readers have already weighed in on the debate, which centered on the protections of free speech.

title: Like Car Talk, but With Dead People
description: On a sunny September morning in the Bronx, Vincent and Robert Gardino were out searching for the dead. Strolling among the tombstones in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, the brothers were not the least bit morbid, excitedly trading stories and barbs.

title: Wus Wonton King
description: Some of the best dishes at this restaurant, where Chinatown meets the Lower East Side, are the simplest, along with the whole suckling pig.

title: Where Dumplings and Ducks Rule
description: Two Dungeness crabs face off on the plate, ready to duel. One is battered gold, deep-fried and propped on a rubble of garlic shards; the other has been steamed to a dying-sunset hue and shimmers from a frisk in the wok with ginger, scallions and Shaoxing wine. Only a border of half-moon cucumbers separates them, keeping the peace.

title: Review: An Anime New York in Netflixs Neo Yokio
description: Among the notable attributes of Neo Yokio, a new fantasy-comedy anime sendup on Netflix:

title: Tax Reform for the Rich: Reduce the Rates but Lose the Breaks
description: When the Trump administration unveils new details of its tax plan, promised for next week, one group of taxpayers will be under the microscope: the rich.

title: New Trailer: In Isle of Dogs, Wes Anderson Returns to Animation
description: Nearly a decade after making his first foray into animation with The Fantastic Mr. Fox, the writer-director Wes Anderson returns to the stop-motion technique and focuses on another type of animal in Isle of Dogs.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Battle of the Sexes
description: Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris discuss a sequence from their film featuring Emma Stone and Andrea Riseborough.

title: Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris Narrate a Scene From Battle of the Sexes
description: While the movie Battle of the Sexes does lead up to the  1973 tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobbie Riggs, it takes some time to explore close moments between its characters off the court.

title: A Late-Night Radio Drama, With Hints of the Internet to Come
description: Stanley Elkins third novel, The Dick Gibson Show (1971), is not improving to read. Its heart is not in the right place. It squeezes the blackheads behind the ears of your imagination; its a Diane Arbus walk on the unreconciled side. Its among the most powerful and funny American novels I know.

title: Should I Track Down the Girl I Bullied in Middle School?
description: Ten years ago, when I was 14 (and starting to freak out that I might be a lesbian), I spread some mean rumors about a girl in my class. I said that shed come on to me and that Id seen her making out with another girl. Neither story was true. And they caused her a lot of trouble. Ive felt terrible about this for years. But I havent seen her since we graduated. Should I track her down and apologize?

title: Four Modern Masters of Color Reinvigorating Design
description: The Color Field painters of the late 1940s and 1950s exploded many ideas about what art should and shouldnt be, but one of their greatest and most enduring influences was the assertion that color has its own power, one apart from and even surpassing that of figurative representation. Mark Rothko, for example, wanted viewers to stand close to his paintings, to be enveloped by their hues, to have a mythic, transcendent experience with his work. In the words of critic Calvin Tomkins, the painter sought to depict color itself, color liberated and breathing within the alternative world of the picture.

title: A Composers Debut, at 82
description: Some people are late bloomers. Then there is Richard Alan White, 82, who was a composer-in-hiding for the first eight decades of his life.

title: And Now a Fifth Game of Thrones Prequel Is in the Works
description: The pool of potential Game of Thrones prequels has expanded, and the latest concept will come from core members of the Westeros braintrust.

title: Review: Advantage, Bobby, but Game, Set, Match, Billie Jean in Battle of the Sexes
description: Every so often an exceptionally capable woman has to prove her worth by competing against a clown. Thats one of the durable truisms of Battle of the Sexes, a glib, enjoyable fictionalization of the 1973 exhibition tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs. She was 29 and one of the top female tennis players in the world. He was 55 and had been a world champion before she was born. She was a feminist symbol and the first female athlete to win more than $100,000 in a single year; he was a self-avowed male chauvinist pig who liked to gamble big. It was a man vs. woman match made for maximum public-relations gimmickry but also a deadly serious referendum on equality on and off the court.

title: 20 Under $20
description: Twenty exciting value wines to drink right now.

title: 20 Wines for Under $20: Weeknight Pleasures for Relaxed Evenings
description: The requirements for weeknight cooking are easy to understand, but weeknight wine? Its a bit more conceptual.

title: A French Theater Impresario, Dressed for Excess
description: One of the most powerful men in European theater was flat on his back, merrily pedaling in the air. The floor-length dress, platinum wig and tiara were a nice touch, and the pendulous rhinestone earring caught the light of BAMs Fishman Space.

title: Liliane Bettencourt, LOral Heiress Vexed by Swindling Case, Is Dead at 94
description: Liliane Bettencourt, the French heiress to the LOral cosmetics fortune and a family legacy of fascist associations, whose final years were vexed by allegations that she had fallen under the sway of a younger man and given him $1.4 billion, died on Wednesday at her home in the Paris suburb Neuilly-sur-Seine. She was 94.

title: Skadden, Big New York Law Firm, Faces Questions on Work With Manafort
description: WASHINGTON  Five years ago, Paul Manafort arranged for a prominent New York-based law firm to draft a report that was used by allies of his client, Viktor Yanukovych, the Russia-aligned president of Ukraine, to justify the jailing of a political rival. And now the report is coming back to haunt it.

title: The Remarkable Patience of the Staten Island Bat Watchers
description: On the deserted edge of Freshkills on Staten Island, winged shadows swooped through night sky. Wearing a headlamp, Danielle Fibikar, a wildlife biologist and an educator at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden, adjusted the nets she had set out to catch bats.

title: Citizens Mobilize After Mexico Quake
description: Volunteers are banding together to help rescue workers clear rubble and distribute resources after the 7.1 magnitude earthquake shook Mexico City on Tuesday.

title: 3 Police Chiefs Are Killed in a Month in a Volatile Afghan District
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The police chief of a volatile Afghanistan district was killed by a roadside bomb on Thursday, officials said, just two weeks after taking over for his predecessor, who was killed in the same manner.

title: Still Processing: Outrage Over Bodega and Horror at the Movies
description: Last week, a Silicon Valley startup called Bodega instigated an internet meltdown after a Fast Company profile made the companys intentions clear. Eventually, centralized shopping locations wont be necessary, because there will be 100,000 Bodegas spread out, with one always 100 feet away from you, said Paul McDonald, a co-founder, who used to work at Google. The outrage made moral sense. Bodega is name thats asking for trouble, especially with people who frequent them. The outrage is also easy. Wheres the upset over the effect other, bigger companies  like Amazon, whose latest major acquisition, Whole Foods, has slashed prices  might actually have on bodegas? Being mad at Amazon is harder when its mixed up in so much of your life. We discuss the dilemma.

title: Confirm or Deny: Judi Dench
description: Maureen Dowd: Youre bored with playing queens?

title: Queen! Bow Down to Tattoo-Flashing Octogenarian Dame Dench
description: I watch as Dame Judi Dench eats her chilled corn soup with saffron and sips Champagne. At 82, she is just as elegant as you would imagine, with silver hair, ice-blue eyes and crisp diction. Shes 5-foot-1, but her reputation is towering.

title: N.F.L. Week 3 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Expectations have to be adjusted throughout the league as teams like Denver and New England looked far better in Week 2 than they had in Week 1, while Dallas and Green Bay fell off a cliff. There is still too much noise in any of the results to draw too many conclusions, but the N.F.L.s hierarchy might get some clarity this week. Here is who we pick.

title: Far-Right German Party Is Poised to Break Postwar Taboo
description: BERLIN  In an unpredictable political year across Europe, the German election on Sunday has been considered the boring final act. Angela Merkel, the Continents most powerful figure, is expected to win a fourth term as chancellor after a colorless campaign. Yet if many Germans seem satisfied enough with their leader, others are unhappy with the wishy-washy consensus of the main political parties.

title: Is This the Least-Loved Highway in America?
description: You look up from underneath the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, or its extension, the Gowanus Expressway, and if it happens to be one of those rare moments when traffic is actually moving, you could fill a bookcase with the stories going on overhead, all endeavoring furiously to be elsewhere. On the B.Q.E., even more than on most highways, success means getting off it. It is a non-place, measured in units of time, not distance. Its existence expresses a builders preference  in this case, Robert Mosess  for automobiles over the communities of people living below.

title: Ryanair Apologizes Over Mass Cancellations Caused by Pilot Vacations
description: Ryanairs chief executive apologized to shareholders and customers on Thursday, looking to stanch criticism over the cancellation of more than 2,100 flights after it scheduled too many pilots for vacation.

title: Pressure Mounts on Iraqi Kurds to Cancel Independence Vote
description: ERBIL, Iraq  In a region where few people concur on anything, adversaries and enemies in the Middle East find themselves agreeing on one goal: to stop Iraqs Kurds from forging ahead with a vote for independence on Monday.

title: For Neanderthals, Growing Big Brains Took More Time
description: We modern humans like to boast about our big brains, but the Neanderthals seem to have had even larger ones.

title: Peabody Essex Museum Gets Set of Native American Artifacts
description: A noted collection of more than 150 Native American artifacts, including wampum belts and finely beaded ceremonial garb, will stay  for now  where it has been housed for almost 70 years, at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., officials announced Thursday.

title: Behind the Scenes with Gigi Hadid

title: 48 Hours in London with Gigi Hadid
description: Its early Monday afternoon at the Tommy Hilfiger showroom in Knightsbridge, West London  a four-story monument to preppy American style in bright primary colors  and Gigi Hadid, the 22-year-old half-Dutch half-Palestinian model is showing me the collection she codesigned with Hilfiger, titled Tommy X Gigi, that will be shown at the historic music venue The Roundhouse the following night. This is my favorite piece, she coos, picking out a vintage-looking oversize leather jacket with her name emblazoned in red lettering on the back. I get very excited when things turn out the way you envision it.

title: The Allure of Black-Colored Food
description: WE KNOW ONLY a few grim details of the Hell Banquet, which took place in the first century A.D. The host: the glowering, paranoid Roman emperor Domitian, never happier than when executing opponents in the senate. The setting: a room black from floor to ceiling, lit by low-burning lamps, with each guests name engraved on a tombstone-like stela. The food: of the kind normally offered to the dead, and entirely black.

title: Documentas Athens Venue Was a Costly Success, Officials Say
description: Berlin  The budget of Documenta, the pace-setting quinquennial exhibition of contemporary art traditionally hosted in Kassel, Germany, ran $8 million over budget primarily due to costs incurred at a second venue this year in Athens, officials said Thursday.

title: A Glowing Cotton Study That Might Have Deserved Less Glowing Reviews

Journalists enthusiastically covered the paper, published in Science. It could be the biggest advance in cotton technology since Eli Whitneys gin, an article in Forbes reported.

title: Most Seen on Stage? Shakespeare the Character, Not the Playwright
description: Works by Shakespeare arent counted. But works about Shakespeare are. A survey by American Theater magazine shows that Shakespeare in Love, the 2014 play about young Wills formative years, adapted by Lee Hall from the wildly successful 1998 film version, will be the most produced play in the United States during the 2017-18 theatrical season.

title: President Trump Inside and Outside the Lines at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  It was hardly a surprise that Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate impresario-turned-leader of the free world, would mix awkwardly with the highly scripted, scrupulously diplomatic crowd that converges here for the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Baseball Needs More Netting, and Fewer Excuses
description: A little girl, a strawberry blonde, was hit in the face with a 105-mile-per-hour line drive Wednesday afternoon at Yankee Stadium. A fan sitting near her said, There was so much blood. In the arms of her grandfather, her small body was limp as he carried her out of the stands.

title: Trump Poised to Drop Some Limits on Drone Strikes and Commando Raids
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is preparing to dismantle key Obama-era limits on drone strikes and commando raids outside conventional battlefields, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations. The changes would lay the groundwork for possible counterterrorism missions in countries where Islamic militants are active but the United States has not previously tried to kill or capture them.

title: For Puerto Ricans Off the Island, a Struggle to Make Contact After Maria
description: For the more than five million Puerto Ricans living on the United States mainland, it was bad enough to watch news reports on Wednesday of Hurricane Maria ripping through an island where relatives and friends lived. What made it worse was not knowing how their loved ones had fared.

title: Scott Perry, New Knicks G.M., Likes Things Clean and Neat
description: Scott Perry, the Knicks new general manager, has been in New York for more than a month, but the walls of his office at the teams practice center in Tarrytown remain bare. title: Stunned by Quake, Mexican Town Fears It Will Never Be the Same
description: JOJUTLA, Mexico  The remnants of their life lay before them like some crude exhibit in a gallery of loss: a pink Bible, a Mickey Mouse T-shirt, earthenware plates and enamel pots.

title: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Fall fiction is here and ready to entertain you, as new novels by Nicole Krauss, Salman Rushdie and Nathan Englander can attest. In nonfiction, enhance your viewing of Ken Burnss Vietnam War with James Reston Jr.s A Rift in the Earth, the story of the controversy over Maya Lins Vietnam memorial. Two illuminating memoirs  one by a candidate, one by a journalist  will plunge you back into the thick of the 2016 election, but if that history is still a little too close for comfort, you can always take refuge in Scaachi Kouls irreverent essay collection, One Day Well All Be Dead and None of This Will Matter.

Senator Luther Strange used every opportunity he had at a Republican candidate forum here on Thursday to invoke his support from President Trump as he defended his seat against former state Supreme Court Justice Roy Moore, who unfurled a litany of accusations against Mr. Strange and ridiculed his reliance on the presidents endorsement just days before they face off in Alabamas special Senate election.

title: I Wanted to Play Football. Mom Wouldnt Let Me.
description: After reading the Times story this week about new evidence that playing tackle football, especially before the age of 12, may lead to diminished cognitive function later in life, my first thought was, Thanks, Mom.

title: World Hunger Haunts the U.N. Festivities
description: As the leaders of the world posture and sermonize for the United Nations General Assembly this week, a growing global specter should spur common concern among them: World hunger, after a decade-long decline, spiked last year, because of scourges like global warming and civil conflicts that show little sign of abating.

title: In Rome, a Visit With the Anti-Trump
description: ROME  Walking to the Eternal City, over stones worn down by the sandals of centurions, on a pilgrims path nearly forgotten in all the layers of Italian time, the mind focuses as the muscles stiffen.
